name: Green Texas Cichlid (Herichthys cyanoguttatus) 4-6cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Green Texas Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Herichthys carpintis
    • Common name: Green Texas Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Eastern Mexico, particularly the Pánuco River basin
    • Adult length: 25 to 30 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 to 12 years
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate to Advanced
    • Temperament: Aggressive and territorial

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Green Texas Cichlids need a spacious tank, ideally 300L or more, to thrive and establish territory.
    • Provide a rocky aquascape with caves, driftwood, and robust décor to allow for territorial boundaries.
    • Use tough or artificial plants, as they tend to dig and may uproot delicate greenery.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH between 6.5 and 8.0.
    • Temperature should be kept between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • Water hardness should be moderate to hard.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a high-capacity filter like a canister or sump to handle bioload and maintain excellent water quality.
    • Moderate flow is ideal to simulate riverine conditions without stressing the fish.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed a high-quality cichlid pellet or flake as a base.
    • Supplement with frozen or live foods such as bloodworms, krill, and brine shrimp.
    • Include some vegetable matter like spirulina flakes or blanched spinach to maintain digestion and colouration.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Best kept with other large, robust cichlids or armored catfish like plecos.
    • Do not house with small or peaceful species, as they may be bullied or eaten.
    • Use caution with mixing males and females unless breeding is intended, as aggression may spike during spawning.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Green Texas Cichlids are intelligent, aggressive, and highly territorial, especially in confined spaces.
    • They may become more manageable with age, but should always be monitored in community tanks.
    • Best suited for species-only setups or carefully planned cichlid communities with ample space and visual breaks.

name: Ellioti Cichlid (Thorichthys ellioti) 4-5cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Ellioti Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Thorichthys ellioti
    • Common name: Ellioti Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America, found in Mexico, Guatemala, and Honduras
    • Adult length: 10 - 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 - 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Ellioti Cichlids require a tank of at least 30 gallons.
    • Provide hiding places with rocks, caves, and driftwood to mimic their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Ellioti Cichlids prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Adequate filtration is necessary to maintain water quality, and a moderate water flow is suitable for these fish.

  5. Diet:

    • Ellioti Cichlids are omnivores and accept a variety of foods including high-quality cichlid pellets, flakes, and live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.
    • Offer a balanced diet to ensure their health and vitality.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Ellioti Cichlids can be territorial, especially during breeding, so choose tank mates carefully.
    • Compatible tank mates include other Central American cichlids of similar size and temperament, as well as peaceful dither fish like tetras and rasboras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Ellioti Cichlids are generally peaceful but can become territorial during spawning.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and break lines of sight in the tank to reduce aggression.

name: Threadfin Acara Cichlid (Acarichthys heckelii)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Threadfin Acara Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Acarichthys heckelii
    • Common name: Threadfin Acara Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: South America
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Threadfin Acara Cichlids prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots and caves. A tank size of at least 75 gallons is recommended.
    • Provide a substrate of sand or fine gravel and decorate the tank with driftwood, rocks, and live plants to mimic their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Threadfin Acara Cichlids thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Threadfin Acara Cichlids are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality pellets, flakes, and live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Threadfin Acara Cichlids are generally peaceful but may become territorial during breeding. They can be kept with other peaceful cichlids, tetras, rasboras, and other similarly sized community fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Threadfin Acara Cichlids are relatively peaceful and can be kept in community tanks with other non-aggressive fish species.
    • They may display some territorial behavior, especially during breeding, so provide plenty of hiding spots and territories within the tank.

name: Checkerboard Dwarf Cichlid (Dicrossus filamentosus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Checkerboard Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Dicrossus filamentosus
    • Common name: Checkerboard Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: South America, Amazon River Basin
    • Adult length: 5-6 cm
    • Lifespan: 3-5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Provide a tank with plenty of hiding spots such as caves, driftwood, and plants to mimic their natural habitat.
    • They prefer soft, acidic water conditions with a pH range of 5.5 to 7.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Checkerboard Cichlids thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for Checkerboard Cichlids, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Checkerboard Cichlids are carnivorous and prefer live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.
    • Offer them high-quality cichlid pellets or flakes as a staple diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Checkerboard Cichlids are relatively peaceful but can be territorial during breeding. They can be kept with other small, peaceful fish that can tolerate their water requirements.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Checkerboard Cichlids are relatively peaceful cichlids but can be territorial during breeding.
    • They are best kept in pairs or small groups in a species tank or a community tank with other peaceful fish.

name: Lemon Oscar Cichlid (Astronotus ocellatus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Lemon Oscar Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Astronotus ocellatus
    • Common name: Lemon Oscar Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: Up to 14 inches
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Lemon Oscar Cichlids need a spacious tank with a minimum size of 75 gallons for a single fish and larger for multiple Oscars.
    • Include hiding spots with caves, rocks, and driftwood. They may rearrange the tank decor, so secure items firmly.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH range between 6.5 to 7.5 for Lemon Oscar Cichlids.
    • Keep the water temperature between 74 to 81°F.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a powerful filter to handle the waste produced by Lemon Oscar Cichlids. They appreciate clean and well-oxygenated water.

  5. Diet:

    • Lemon Oscar Cichlids are carnivores, and their diet should include high-quality pellets, live or frozen foods such as earthworms, crickets, and feeder fish.
    • Offer a varied diet to ensure they receive essential nutrients. Avoid overfeeding to prevent obesity.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Lemon Oscar Cichlids can be territorial and aggressive, so choose tank mates carefully. Avoid small or passive fish.
    • Consider larger, robust companions like other cichlids, large catfish, and certain plecos.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Lemon Oscar Cichlids are intelligent and can recognize their owners. They may display interactive behaviors like begging for food.
    • Monitor their interactions with tank mates to prevent aggression, especially during breeding periods.

name: Festivum Cichlid (Mesonauta festivus) 3.5-4cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Festivum Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Mesonauta festivus
    • Common name: Festivum Cichlid, Flag Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: South America, specifically in the Amazon River basin
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Festivum Cichlids appreciate a tank with plenty of hiding spots and territories. Provide caves, driftwood, and plants like Java Fern and Amazon Sword for them to claim as their own.
    • They prefer subdued lighting and a sandy substrate to mimic their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • Maintain a pH level around 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Aim for efficient filtration to keep the water clean, as Festivum Cichlids are sensitive to poor water quality.
    • Provide gentle to moderate water flow as they prefer calmer waters.

  5. Diet:

    • Festivum Cichlids are omnivores and will accept a varied diet. Offer them high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.
    • Include vegetable matter in their diet, such as blanched spinach or zucchini slices.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are generally peaceful but can be territorial during breeding. Suitable tank mates include other peaceful community fish like tetras, peaceful barbs, and catfish species.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or overly territorial fish that may provoke them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Festivum Cichlids are relatively peaceful but can show aggression during breeding or when defending territories.
    • They are best kept in pairs or small groups, ensuring each fish has enough space and hiding spots.

name: Red Head Tapajos Geophagus Cichlid (Geophagus sp. Tapajos) 10cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Red Head Tapajos Geophagus Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Geophagus sp. "Tapajos Red Head"
    • Common name: Red Head Tapajos Geophagus
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Tapajos River, Brazil
    • Adult length: Up to 20 cm (8 inches)
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Red Head Tapajos Geophagus thrive in a spacious tank with sandy substrate and plenty of hiding spots. A tank size of at least 50 gallons is recommended for a pair or small group.
    • Provide flat rocks and smooth decorations for them to establish territories. They appreciate areas with moderate water flow.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Red Head Tapajos Geophagus prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Red Head Tapajos Geophagus are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small invertebrates.
    • Include vegetable matter in their diet, such as spirulina-based foods or blanched vegetables.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Red Head Tapajos Geophagus are generally peaceful but can be territorial during breeding. They can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size and temperament.
    • Compatible tank mates include other cichlids, tetras, rasboras, and peaceful catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Red Head Tapajos Geophagus are known for their digging behavior, so provide a substrate that allows them to sift through and sift the sand.
    • They may exhibit more vibrant colors during breeding, and it's advisable to provide ample hiding spots for potential fry.

name: Black Nasty Cichlid (Nandopsis haitiensis) 7-10cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Black Nasty Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Nandopsis haitiensis
    • Common name: Black Nasty Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America, specifically Haiti
    • Adult length: Approximately 30 cm (12 inches)
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Black Nasty Cichlids require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and territories. A tank size of at least 75 gallons is recommended for a single fish or pair.
    • Provide rocky caves, driftwood, and robust plants to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate areas with strong water flow.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Black Nasty Cichlids prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a powerful filtration system to maintain water quality, as Black Nasty Cichlids are messy eaters and produce a lot of waste.
    • They appreciate moderate to strong water flow in the tank.

  5. Diet:

    • Black Nasty Cichlids are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small feeder fish.
    • Vegetable matter should also be included in their diet, such as blanched vegetables or spirulina-based foods.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Black Nasty Cichlids are territorial and can be aggressive towards other fish, especially during breeding. They are best kept with larger, robust species that can hold their own, such as other large cichlids from Central America.
    • Avoid keeping them with small or timid fish that may be intimidated or harassed.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Black Nasty Cichlids are aggressive and territorial, especially when breeding. They should be housed in a species-only tank or with other large, robust cichlids.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and territories to reduce aggression.

name: Albino Convict Cichlid (Amatitlania nigrofasciata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Albino Convict Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Amatitlania nigrofasciata
    • Common name: Albino Convict Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America (Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica, and Panama)
    • Adult length: 10 cm (4 inches)
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Albino Convict Cichlids can be kept in tanks as small as 20 gallons, but a larger tank of 30 gallons or more is recommended for a breeding pair or community setup.
    • They appreciate a setup with caves, rocks, and driftwood to mimic their natural habitat. Live plants are optional as they may uproot them.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Albino Convict Cichlids prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH ranging from 6.5 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 20 to 28°C (68 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A good filtration system is essential as Albino Convict Cichlids are messy eaters and produce a significant amount of waste. A filter rated for the size of your tank is recommended.

  5. Diet:

    • Albino Convict Cichlids are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food supplemented with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Albino Convict Cichlids can be aggressive, especially during breeding, so choose tank mates carefully. Avoid keeping them with small or passive fish that may become targets of aggression.
    • They are often kept with other robust cichlid species from Central America or similarly sized fish that can hold their own.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Albino Convict Cichlids are known for their territorial behavior, especially when breeding. Provide plenty of hiding spots and territories within the tank to reduce aggression.
    • They are good parents and will protect their fry vigorously. Breeding pairs may become more aggressive, so it's essential to have a plan for fry management if breeding is not desired.

name: Parrot Cichlid (Hybrid)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Polar Parrot Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name:
    • Common name: Polar Parrot Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America, primarily Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica
    • Adult length: 10 cm (4 inches)
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • They can thrive in tanks as small as 20 gallons, but larger tanks are recommended for more aggressive setups or larger groups.
    • Provide hiding spots and territories with rocks, caves, and driftwood. They enjoy rearranging their environment, so ensure decorations are stable.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Polar Parrot Cichlid prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.0.
    • Water temperature should be maintained between 75 to 80°F (24 to 27°C).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Ensure strong filtration to maintain water quality, as they can be messy eaters.
    • They prefer moderate water flow, so adjust filtration accordingly.

  5. Diet:

    • Polar Parrot Cichlid are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including pellets, flakes, and frozen or live foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.
    • Offer a balanced diet to promote health and coloration.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Platinum Polar Parrot Cichlid can be territorial and aggressive, especially during breeding, so choose tank mates carefully.
    • Compatible tank mates include robust species like other Central American cichlids, larger tetras, and barbs.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • They are known for their breeding behavior, and they may become territorial during this time.
    • They can be kept in pairs or small groups, but avoid keeping multiple breeding pairs in the same tank unless it's very large with plenty of hiding spots.

name: Assorted Swordtails (Xiphophorus helleri)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Swordtail Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus helleri
    • Common name: Swordtail
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America, Mexico
    • Adult length: 12 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Swordtails thrive in a tank with a minimum size of 75L. Ensure the tank has open swimming spaces and some hiding spots created by plants and decorations.
    • Include hardy plants like Java Moss and Vallisneria, and maintain a substrate that allows them to exhibit their natural digging behavior.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water conditions slightly alkaline to neutral with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.3.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 22 to 27°C (72 to 80°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a moderate filter to ensure proper water circulation, but avoid strong currents that may stress the fish.

  5. Diet:

    • Swordtails are omnivores and will accept various foods. Provide a balanced diet with high-quality flakes or pellets as a staple.
    • Include live or frozen foods like brine shrimp, bloodworms, and daphnia to enhance their diet and promote optimal health.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Swordtails are generally peaceful and can be kept with other community fish such as tetras, barbs, and peaceful cichlids.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species to prevent stress and injuries.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Swordtails are active swimmers and may display some territorial behavior, especially among males. Provide ample space and maintain a proper sex ratio to reduce aggression.
    • They are compatible with a variety of community fish, but monitor their interactions to ensure a harmonious tank environment.

name: Assorted Molly (Poecilia sphenops)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Mollies

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia sphenops
    • Common name: Common Molly
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central and South America
    • Adult length: 5 cm (2 inches)
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Mollies prefer a tank with a minimum size of 40 litres (10 gallons).
    • Provide plenty of plants, driftwood, and hiding places, as well as open swimming areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 25 to 28°C (77 to 82°F).
    • Maintain a pH level between 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Hardness: 20 to 30 dGH.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A good filtration system is necessary to maintain water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed Mollies a varied diet including high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods such as bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Mollies are peaceful and active fish, and they do well in community tanks.
    • They are livebearers and can reproduce quickly under suitable conditions.

name: Assorted Platy (Xiphophorus maculatus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Play Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus maculatus
    • Common name: Platy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America, from southern Mexico to Guatemala
    • Adult length: 3 to 7 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 4 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Platies are adaptable and can thrive in various tank sizes, but a minimum of 20L per fish is recommended to ensure adequate space.
    • They appreciate a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Platies prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for platies, so choose a filter that provides adequate but not excessive flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Platies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Platies are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as tetras, guppies, mollies, and peaceful barbs.
    • They should not be kept with aggressive or fin-nipping species that may stress or harm them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Platies are active swimmers and are best kept in groups of at least five individuals to ensure social interaction and minimize stress.
    • They are known for their peaceful nature and can coexist with a variety of tank mates.

name: Assorted Female Guppy (Poecilia reticulata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia reticulata
    • Common name: Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Northeastern South America
    • Adult length: 2.5 - 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 - 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 10 gallons, but a larger tank around 20 gallons or more is recommended for a community setup.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and plants, as well as open swimming areas. Guppies appreciate live or artificial plants for cover.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Guppies prefer slightly hard water with a pH range between 7.0 and 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Good filtration is essential for maintaining water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for guppies.

  5. Diet:

    • Guppies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including flake, pellet, and live foods.
    • Offer them a varied diet including high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple, supplemented with occasional treats like bloodworms, brine shrimp, or daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Guppies are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size. Avoid keeping them with fin-nipping or aggressive species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Guppies are active and social fish that do best in groups. Keeping them in schools of 6 or more will help reduce stress and encourage natural behaviors.
    • They are generally compatible with other peaceful community fish, but avoid keeping them with larger, aggressive species that may intimidate or prey on them.

name: Humpback Limia Pair (Limia nigrofasciata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Humpback Limia Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Limia nigrofasciata
    • Common name: Humpback Limia
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Caribbean
    • Adult length: Up to 5 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Humpback Limias are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 20 litres, but a larger tank of around 60 litres or more is recommended for a small group.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots with rocks, driftwood, and live plants such as Java Moss and Anubias.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Temperature: 23-28°C (73-82°F)
    • pH: 7.0-8.0
    • Hardness: 10-20 dGH

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle filtration system with moderate water flow is suitable.

  5. Diet:

    • Humpback Limias are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other small, peaceful fish such as other livebearers, tetras, and rasboras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Humpback Limias are peaceful fish that can be kept in groups and are suitable for community tanks.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping tank mates.

name: Butterfly Splitfin (Ameca splendens)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Butterfly Splitfin Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Ameca splendens
    • Common name: Butterfly Splitfin
    • Family: Goodeidae
    • Origin: Mexico
    • Adult length: 7 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Butterfly Splitfins thrive in well-planted aquariums with hiding spots and open swimming areas.
    • Provide a tank size of at least 75L for a small group, and use fine-gravel substrate.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 25°C (72 to 77°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filter to ensure proper water quality without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Butterfly Splitfins are herbivores, so include high-quality vegetable-based flakes or pellets in their diet.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional live or frozen foods like brine shrimp and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful fish and can be kept with other community fish of similar size and temperament.
    • Avoid aggressive or fin-nipping species that may stress the Butterfly Splitfins.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Butterfly Splitfins are social and should be kept in groups of at least four individuals.
    • They exhibit interesting behaviors, including grazing on algae, so provide suitable environments for these activities.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Butterfly Splitfins are social and should be kept in groups of at least four individuals.
    • They exhibit interesting behaviors, including grazing on algae, so provide suitable environments for these activities.

name: Bumblebee Platy (Xiphophorus maculatus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Bumblebee Platy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus maculatus
    • Common name: Bumblebee Platy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America, from southern Mexico to Guatemala
    • Adult length: 3 to 7 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 4 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Bumblebee Platies are adaptable and can thrive in various tank sizes, but a minimum of 20L per fish is recommended to ensure adequate space.
    • They appreciate a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Bumblebee Platies prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for Bumblebee platies, so choose a filter that provides adequate but not excessive flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Bumblebee Platies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Bumblebee Platies are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as tetras, guppies, mollies, and peaceful barbs.
    • They should not be kept with aggressive or fin-nipping species that may stress or harm them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Bumblebee Platies are active swimmers and are best kept in groups of at least five individuals to ensure social interaction and minimize stress.
    • They are known for their peaceful nature and can coexist with a variety of tank mates.

name: Perugia's Limia (Limia perugiae)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Perugia’s Limia Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Limia perugiae
    • Common name: Perugia’s Limia
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Jamaica
    • Adult length: 5-7 cm
    • Lifespan: 3-5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Provide a tank size of at least 20 gallons for a small group of Limia perugiae.
    • Decorate the tank with plants like Java Moss and Vallisneria for cover and hiding spots.
    • Ensure the tank has a lid as Limia perugiae are known to jump.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a temperature between 24-28°C (75-82°F) and a pH level of 7.0-8.0.
    • Keep the water hardness between 20-30 dGH.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a filter suitable for the tank size with moderate water flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Offer a varied diet including high-quality flake, pellet, and vegetable-based foods.
    • Supplement with live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Perugia’s Limia are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful community fish like tetras, rasboras, and peaceful barbs.
    • Avoid aggressive or fin-nipping fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Perugia’s Limia are generally peaceful but may show territorial behavior, especially during breeding.
    • They are livebearers and can breed easily in the aquarium.

name: Albino Koi Swordtail (Xiphophorus hellerii)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Albino Koi Swordtail Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus helleri
    • Common name: Albino Koi Swordtail
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America, Mexico
    • Adult length: 12 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Albino Koi Swordtails thrive in a tank with a minimum size of 75L. Ensure the tank has open swimming spaces and some hiding spots created by plants and decorations.
    • Include hardy plants like Java Moss and Vallisneria, and maintain a substrate that allows them to exhibit their natural digging behavior.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water conditions slightly alkaline to neutral with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.3.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 22 to 27°C (72 to 80°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a moderate filter to ensure proper water circulation, but avoid strong currents that may stress the fish.

  5. Diet:

    • Albino Koi Swordtails are omnivores and will accept various foods. Provide a balanced diet with high-quality flakes or pellets as a staple.
    • Include live or frozen foods like brine shrimp, bloodworms, and daphnia to enhance their diet and promote optimal health.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Albino Koi Swordtails are generally peaceful and can be kept with other community fish such as tetras, barbs, and peaceful cichlids.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species to prevent stress and injuries.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Albino Koi Swordtails are active swimmers and may display some territorial behavior, especially among males. Provide ample space and maintain a proper sex ratio to reduce aggression.
    • They are compatible with a variety of community fish, but monitor their interactions to ensure a harmonious tank environment.

name: Variatus Platy (Xiphophorus variatus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Variatus Platy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus variatus
    • Common name: Variatus Platy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Eastern and Central Mexico
    • Adult length: 4 to 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Variatus Platys thrive in a well-planted tank with open swimming areas. A minimum tank size of 40L is suitable for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide hiding spots with decorations or plants, and ensure the tank has some floating plants to diffuse light.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Variatus Platys prefer slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 20 to 26°C (68 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter with adjustable flow settings.

  5. Diet:

    • Variatus Platys are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet of high-quality flake or pellet food supplemented with live or frozen foods like brine shrimp and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Variatus Platys are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful fish species. They do well in a community tank with other livebearers, tetras, and small catfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Variatus Platys are active and social fish, so keeping them in groups is beneficial for their well-being. They coexist well with other community fish but avoid aggressive tank mates that may stress them.

name: Assorted Balloon Molly (Poecilia sphenops)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Balloon Molly Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia sphenops
    • Common name: Balloon Molly
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central and South America
    • Adult length: 5 cm (2 inches)
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Balloon Mollies prefer a tank with a minimum size of 40 litres (10 gallons).
    • Provide plenty of plants, driftwood, and hiding places, as well as open swimming areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 25 to 28°C (77 to 82°F).
    • Maintain a pH level between 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Hardness: 20 to 30 dGH.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A good filtration system is necessary to maintain water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed Balloon Mollies a varied diet including high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods such as bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Balloon Mollies are peaceful and active fish, and they do well in community tanks.
    • They are livebearers and can reproduce quickly under suitable conditions.

name: Tarzan Blue Guppy Pair (Poecilia reticulata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Tarzan Blue Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia reticulata
    • Common name: Tarzan Blue Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Northeastern South America
    • Adult length: 2.5 - 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 - 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Tarzan Blue Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 10 gallons, but a larger tank around 20 gallons or more is recommended for a community setup.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and plants, as well as open swimming areas. Tarzan Blue Guppies appreciate live or artificial plants for cover.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Tarzan Blue Guppies prefer slightly hard water with a pH range between 7.0 and 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Good filtration is essential for maintaining water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for guppies.

  5. Diet:

    • Tarzan Blue Guppies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including flake, pellet, and live foods.
    • Offer them a varied diet including high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple, supplemented with occasional treats like bloodworms, brine shrimp, or daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Tarzan Blue Guppies are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size. Avoid keeping them with fin-nipping or aggressive species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Tarzan Blue Guppies are active and social fish that do best in groups. Keeping them in schools of 6 or more will help reduce stress and encourage natural behaviors.
    • They are generally compatible with other peaceful community fish, but avoid keeping them with larger, aggressive species that may intimidate or prey on them.

    • Bamboo Shrimp require a tank with a gentle water flow and ample surface area for filter feeding.
    • Provide stable objects like driftwood, rocks, or filter intakes where they can perch and feed.

name: Bloody Mary Red Cherry Shrimp (Neocaridina davidi)

    • Origin: Taiwan
    • Adult length: 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1.5 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Bloody Mary Red Cherry Shrimp thrive in a heavily planted tank with plenty of hiding places like mosses, driftwood, and rocks.
    • They do well in small tanks starting from 10 litres, but larger tanks provide more stable water conditions and space for them to thrive.

    • Bloody Mary Red Cherry Shrimp are omnivores and primarily feed on algae. They also accept commercial shrimp pellets, blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach, and occasional protein-rich foods such as bloodworms.

    • Adult length: 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

    • Blue Dream Shrimp thrive in well-established tanks with plenty of hiding places such as driftwood, rocks, and dense vegetation like Java Moss and Marimo Moss Balls.
    • They appreciate a planted tank with soft substrate to forage and graze on biofilm and algae.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Amano Shrimp thrive in tanks with plenty of hiding places and surfaces for grazing. A minimum tank size of 20L is suitable.

name: Yellow Fire Shrimp (Neocaridina davidi)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Yellow Fire Shrimp

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neocaridina davidi var. "Yellow Fire"
    • Common name: Yellow Fire Shrimp
    • Family: Atyidae
    • Origin: Selectively bred from Neocaridina davidi (originally from Taiwan)
    • Adult length: 3 to 4 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Yellow Fire Shrimp thrive in planted tanks with hiding places and surfaces for algae growth.
    • Provide mosses like Java Moss or other live plants such as Anubias or Cryptocoryne species.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain stable water conditions with a temperature range of 18 to 26°C (65 to 78°F) and a pH of 6.5 to 8.0.
    • They tolerate a wide range of water conditions but prefer slightly alkaline water for breeding.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filter with a sponge or pre-filter to protect shrimp and fry.
    • Provide slow to moderate water flow as Yellow Fire Shrimp prefer calm waters.

  5. Diet:

    • Offer a varied diet including algae wafers, blanched vegetables (like zucchini or spinach), and specialized shrimp pellets.
    • They also feed on biofilm, algae, and leftover fish food in the tank.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Yellow Fire Shrimp are peaceful and can coexist with other gentle community fish that won't prey on them or disturb them.
    • Good tank mates include small fish such as rasboras, tetras, and peaceful livebearers.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • They are active scavengers, constantly foraging and exploring their environment.
    • Avoid housing them with large or aggressive fish species that may harm or eat them.

name: Cherry Shrimp (Neocaridina davidi)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Cherry Shrimp

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neocaridina davidi
    • Common name: Cherry Shrimp
    • Family: Atyidae
    • Origin: Taiwan
    • Adult length: 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 1.5 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Cherry Shrimp thrive in densely planted tanks with lots of hiding places. A minimum tank size of 10 gallons is suitable for a colony of these shrimp.
    • Provide plenty of mosses, such as Java Moss or Christmas Moss, and other plants like Anubias to create a natural environment and to support biofilm growth.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Cherry Shrimp prefer stable water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.0.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 18 to 24°C (64 to 75°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filter or sponge filter to avoid sucking up baby shrimp or causing strong currents that could stress them.

  5. Diet:

    • Cherry Shrimp are scavengers and omnivores, feeding on algae, biofilm, and detritus in the aquarium. Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like zucchini, spinach, or commercial shrimp pellets.
    • Avoid overfeeding to maintain good water quality.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Cherry Shrimp are peaceful and can be kept with other non-aggressive species like small peaceful fish (e.g., small tetras, rasboras, guppies), snails, and other dwarf shrimp species.
    • Avoid keeping them with large or aggressive fish that may prey on or harass them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Cherry Shrimp are active scavengers and breed readily in suitable conditions. They are best kept in groups to enhance their activity levels and breeding behavior.
    • Provide adequate hiding places to help them feel secure and reduce stress.

name: Crystal Red Shrimp (Caridina cantonensis)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Crystal Red Shrimp

    • Scientific name: Caridina cantonensis

    • Family: Atyidae
    • Origin: Southern China
    • Adult length: 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Crystal Red Shrimp prefer a well-established planted tank with hiding places such as driftwood, rocks, and moss. A tank size of at least 10L is recommended for a small group.
    • Ensure stable water parameters and a gentle filtration system to maintain water quality without strong currents.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Crystal Red Shrimp thrive in soft, slightly acidic water conditions with a pH range of 6.2 to 6.8.

name: Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snail (Marisa cornuarietis)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Marisa cornuarietis
    • Common name: Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snail
    • Family: Ampullariidae
    • Origin: Northern and Western South America
    • Adult size: Up to 5 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snails can thrive in a variety of tank sizes, but a minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group.
    • Provide surfaces for them to climb and explore, such as rocks, driftwood, and aquarium-safe decorations.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails can tolerate a wide range of water conditions, but they prefer slightly alkaline to neutral water with a pH between 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain water temperature between 18 to 28°C (65 to 82°F).

  4. Diet:

    • Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snails are herbivores and will consume algae, biofilm, and leftover fish food. Provide vegetable-based sinking pellets or blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach.
    • Occasional supplementation with calcium-rich foods like cuttlebone or specialized snail foods can help maintain shell health.

  5. Tank mates:

    • They are generally peaceful and can coexist with most fish species that won't prey on them. Avoid keeping them with aggressive or predatory fish.
    • Compatible tank mates include community fish like tetras, guppies, and peaceful cichlids.

  6. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Giant Colombian Ramshorn Snails are active and curious snails that will explore the tank and substrate. They may occasionally climb out of the water, so ensure the tank has a secure lid.
    • They reproduce readily under favorable conditions, so be prepared for population growth if conditions are suitable.

name: Chopstick Snail (Stenomelania torulosa)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Chopstick Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Stenomelania torulosa
    • Common name: Chopstick Snail
    • Family: Thiaridae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including the Philippines, Indonesia, and Malaysia
    • Adult length: 5 to 7 cm
    • Lifespan: Up to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Chopstick Snails prefer a tank with a sandy or fine gravel substrate, which allows them to burrow and search for food.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots with rocks, driftwood, and dense vegetation. Plants such as Java Moss and Anubias are suitable.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group of these snails.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Chopstick Snails thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).
    • These snails prefer a hardness level of 5 to 15 dGH.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is ideal for Chopstick Snails, so choose a filter that provides a slow to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Chopstick Snails are omnivores and scavengers, feeding on algae, detritus, and uneaten fish food. Provide them with a balanced diet that includes algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables such as zucchini or spinach.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional protein sources like bloodworms or shrimp pellets.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Chopstick Snails are peaceful and can be kept with other non-aggressive tank mates such as small community fish, shrimp, and other snails.
    • Avoid housing them with large or aggressive fish that may harm them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Chopstick Snails are generally active and spend a lot of time grazing on surfaces in the tank. They are also known to burrow into the substrate.
    • They are best kept in groups of three or more to encourage natural behaviors.
    • These snails are also known for their ability to reproduce quickly, so monitor their population in the tank to prevent overpopulation.

name: Zebra Nerite Snail (Neritina natalensis)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Zebra Nerite Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neritina natalensis
    • Common name: Zebra Nerite Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Coastal regions of Eastern Africa, particularly in Kenya, Tanzania, and Mozambique
    • Adult length: 2 to 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Zebra Nerite Snails prefer a tank with stable water conditions and plenty of algae for grazing. A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group.
    • Provide smooth surfaces like rocks, driftwood, and glass for them to graze on. Avoid rough or sharp decorations that could damage their delicate bodies.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Zebra Nerite Snails thrive in a wide range of water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is suitable for these snails. Choose a filter that provides mild water movement without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Zebra Nerite Snails are excellent algae eaters and will naturally clean algae off tank surfaces. Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach, and algae wafers if algae growth is insufficient.
    • Avoid overfeeding as uneaten food can lead to water quality issues.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Zebra Nerite Snails are peaceful and can be kept with a variety of tank mates, including small, non-aggressive fish, shrimp, and other peaceful invertebrates.
    • Avoid keeping them with fish species that may prey on or harass them, such as aggressive cichlids or large predatory fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Zebra Nerite Snails are active grazers and spend most of their time cleaning tank surfaces of algae. They are known for their efficient algae-eating capabilities.
    • They are not known to reproduce in freshwater tanks, making them ideal for planted or community aquariums without the risk of overpopulation.

name: Pagoda Snail (Brotia pagodula)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Pagoda Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Brotia pagodula
    • Common name: Pagoda Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, specifically in rivers and streams in Thailand, Laos, and Cambodia
    • Adult length: Up to 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Pagoda Snails prefer a well-maintained tank with a sandy substrate and plenty of rocks and driftwood to explore and hide under.
    • A minimum tank size of 20 litres is recommended for a small group of these snails.
    • Provide ample hiding places and a variety of surfaces for them to graze on, as they are active scavengers.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Pagoda Snails thrive in neutral to slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.2.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).
    • Ensure water hardness is maintained between 8 to 12 dGH to support their shell health.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Moderate water flow is suitable for these snails. Use a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow to avoid disturbing them.

  5. Diet:

    • Pagoda Snails are omnivores and will consume a variety of foods. Offer them a diet consisting of algae wafers, blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach, and sinking pellets.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional protein sources such as shrimp pellets or fish food flakes to ensure balanced nutrition.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Pagoda Snails are peaceful and can be kept with other non-aggressive tank mates such as small fish, shrimp, and other snails.
    • Avoid keeping them with large or aggressive fish species that may prey on them or damage their shells.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Pagoda Snails are active scavengers and will spend most of their time exploring the tank and feeding on detritus and algae.
    • They are best kept in groups to encourage natural behavior and breeding, although they can also be kept individually.

name: Assassin Snail (Clea helena)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Assassin Snail (Clea helena)

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Clea helena
    • Common name: Assassin Snail
    • Family: Buccinidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, particularly Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia
    • Adult length: 2.5 - 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Assassin Snails prefer a tank with a sandy or fine-gravel substrate, which allows them to burrow and mimic their natural habitat.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended, although larger tanks are beneficial if housing multiple snails.
    • Provide hiding spots using rocks, driftwood, or live plants, which also contribute to a more natural environment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Assassin Snails thrive in a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0, indicating slightly alkaline water.
    • Maintain water temperature between 22 to 27°C (72 to 81°F).
    • They are tolerant of a wide range of water hardness but prefer moderately hard to hard water.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is suitable for Assassin Snails, so a filter with low to moderate flow is ideal.

  5. Diet:

    • Assassin Snails are carnivorous and primarily feed on other small snails, making them effective for controlling snail populations in tanks.
    • In the absence of snails, they can be fed sinking foods, frozen bloodworms, and other protein-based foods.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Assassin Snails are peaceful with other fish species but may prey on smaller snails and shrimp.
    • They are compatible with peaceful community fish and other non-snail tank inhabitants, making them versatile for most aquariums.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Assassin Snails are generally solitary but can coexist with others of their species without aggression.
    • They are slow-moving and spend much of their time burrowed in the substrate, ambushing prey snails.

name: Devil Thorn Snail (Faunus ater)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Devil Thorn Snail

    • Provide rocks and driftwood for climbing and grazing. They may also benefit from some areas with dense vegetation.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like zucchini or spinach, as well as algae wafers or sinking pellets.

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with most community fish that won't bother them, such as small tetras, rasboras, and peaceful cichlids.

name: Malaysian Trumpet Snail x 10 (Melanoides tuberculata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Malaysian Trumpet Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Melanoides tuberculata
    • Common name: Malaysian Trumpet Snail
    • Family: Thiaridae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including Malaysia, Thailand, and Indonesia
    • Adult length: Varies, typically up to 2 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Malaysian Trumpet Snails are adaptable and can thrive in various tank sizes. They appreciate tanks with substrate that allows burrowing, such as sand or fine gravel.
    • Provide hiding places like driftwood, rocks, or clay pots for them to retreat into during the day.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • They can tolerate a wide range of water conditions but prefer slightly alkaline to neutral water with a pH between 7.0 and 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for Malaysian Trumpet Snails. Ensure the filter intake is covered to prevent them from getting sucked in.

  5. Diet:

    • They are detritivores and primarily feed on algae, detritus, and leftover fish food. A tank with natural algae growth provides a good food source.
    • Supplement their diet with sinking algae wafers or blanched vegetables like zucchini or cucumber.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Malaysian Trumpet Snails are peaceful and can be kept with a wide range of community fish, including small tetras, rasboras, livebearers, and peaceful dwarf cichlids.
    • They help in maintaining the substrate by burrowing and consuming debris, benefiting the overall tank ecosystem.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • They are nocturnal and often burrow into the substrate during the day, emerging at night to forage.
    • They reproduce readily but are generally beneficial in controlling algae and aerating the substrate.

name: White Wizard Snail (Filopaludina martensi)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping White Wizard Snail

    • White Wizard Snails prefer a tank with plenty of hard surfaces to graze on, such as rocks and aquarium glass.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • They thrive in freshwater or slightly brackish water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • They prefer moderate water flow, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate circulation.

  5. Diet:

    • White Wizard Snails are herbivores and mainly feed on algae. Ensure there is enough algae growth in the tank for them to graze on.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers or blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach if algae growth is insufficient.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful freshwater fish such as tetras, rasboras, guppies, and dwarf shrimp.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or large predatory fish that may harm them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • White Wizard Snails are active grazers and will help control algae growth in the aquarium.
    • They are generally solitary but can be kept in small groups without issues.

name: Black Military Helmet Nerite Snail (Neritina pulligera)

Our Guide To Keeping Black Military Helmet Nerite Snail

name: Yellow Rabbit Snail (Tylomelania patriarchalis)
description:

    • They are peaceful and can be housed with other non-aggressive fish and invertebrates.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers or blanched vegetables like zucchini or cucumber.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can coexist with most fish species that are not aggressive or predatory towards them.
    • Compatible with other peaceful snails and shrimp species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Horned Zebra Nerite Snails are active algae eaters and will graze on surfaces to keep them clean.
    • They may occasionally lay eggs on aquarium surfaces, but these eggs do not hatch in freshwater.

name: Assorted Horned Nerite Snails (Clithon corona)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Horned Nerite Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Clithon corona
    • Common name: Horned Nerite Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including Indonesia and Thailand
    • Adult length: Approximately 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Horned Nerite Snails require a secure lid on the aquarium to prevent escape.
    • Provide a substrate of sand or smooth gravel to prevent damage to their delicate tentacles.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).
    • Keep pH levels stable within the range of 7.5 to 8.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Ensure gentle to moderate water flow to accommodate their preference for calm waters.

  5. Diet:

    • Horned Nerite Snails are herbivores and primarily feed on algae.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers or blanched vegetables like zucchini or cucumber.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can coexist with most fish species that are not aggressive or predatory towards them.
    • Compatible with other peaceful snails and shrimp species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Horned Nerite Snails are active algae eaters and will graze on surfaces to keep them clean.
    • They may occasionally lay eggs on aquarium surfaces, but these eggs do not hatch in freshwater.

name: Batik Nerite Snail (Neritina variegated)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Batik Nerite Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neritina sp.
    • Common name: Batik Nerite Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including Indonesia and Thailand
    • Adult size: Up to 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Batik Nerite Snails require a stable aquarium environment with good water quality.
    • Provide smooth surfaces such as rocks and driftwood for them to graze on.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH level between 7.0 to 8.5 and a water hardness of 5 to 12 dKH.
    • Keep the water temperature in the range of 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filtration system to avoid strong water currents that may stress the snails.

  5. Diet:

    • Batik Nerite Snails are herbivores and feed primarily on algae and biofilm.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers or blanched vegetables like zucchini or cucumber if algae is insufficient.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Batik Nerite Snails are peaceful and can be kept with most freshwater fish and invertebrates.
    • They are particularly beneficial in community tanks for their algae-eating habits.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Batik Nerite Snails are active grazers and will constantly move around the tank in search of algae.
    • They are not known to bother other tank inhabitants and are generally compatible with a wide range of fish species.

name: White Military Helmet Snail (Neritina pulligera)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Military Helmet Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neritina pulligera
    • Common name: Military Helmet Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Tropical freshwater habitats in Southeast Asia
    • Adult length: Varies; typically 2 to 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Military Helmet Snails thrive in aquariums with stable water parameters. They require a secure lid as they can climb and explore above the waterline.
    • Provide smooth surfaces such as rocks and driftwood for grazing and resting, along with plants like Java Moss or Anubias.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Military Helmet Snails prefer freshwater with a neutral to slightly alkaline pH range of 7.0 to 8.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • They tolerate various water flow conditions but prefer moderate flow. Ensure the filter doesn't create strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Military Helmet Snails are herbivores and feed on algae and biofilm. Provide surfaces with algae growth for natural grazing.
    • Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like zucchini or cucumber slices.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Military Helmet Snails are peaceful and can coexist with most community fish that won't harm them or compete for food.
    • They are compatible with small, peaceful fish such as tetras, rasboras, and small catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Military Helmet Snails are nocturnal and may hide during the day, particularly when introduced to a new tank.
    • They are generally compatible with a variety of tank mates but avoid aggressive species that may stress them.

name: Batman Nerite Snail (Neritina auriculata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Batman Nerite Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neritina auriculata
    • Common name: Batman Nerite Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Coastal regions of East Africa, Madagascar, and the Indian Ocean islands
    • Adult length: 2 to 3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Batman Nerite Snails prefer a well-planted tank with plenty of algae and biofilm to graze on. A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group of these snails.
    • Include rocks, driftwood, and other surfaces where algae can grow, providing natural feeding areas for the snails.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Batman Nerite Snails thrive in a wide range of water conditions but prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for Batman Nerite Snails, so choose a filter that provides consistent but not too strong a flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Batman Nerite Snails are excellent algae eaters and will help control algae growth in the tank. Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like zucchini and spinach, and provide algae wafers as necessary.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Batman Nerite Snails are peaceful and can be kept with a variety of community fish. They are compatible with other non-aggressive fish such as tetras, guppies, and peaceful invertebrates like shrimp.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Batman Nerite Snails are generally non-aggressive and spend most of their time grazing on algae and biofilm. They are also known to be escape artists, so ensure the tank has a secure lid to prevent them from climbing out.
    • Avoid keeping them with fish that may see them as prey or are known to be aggressive towards snails, such as certain species of loaches and puffers.

name: Green Torpedo Snail (Cipangopaludina lecythoides)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Green Torpedo Snail

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Cipangopaludina lecythoides
    • Common name: Green Torpedo Snail
    • Family: Viviparidae
    • Origin: East Asia, primarily found in Japan, China, and Korea
    • Adult length: 3 to 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Green Torpedo Snails prefer a tank with a substrate of sand or fine gravel, with plenty of hiding spots and surfaces for grazing. A minimum tank size of 40L is recommended.
    • Incorporate rocks, driftwood, and live plants to provide a natural habitat and additional grazing surfaces.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Green Torpedo Snails thrive in a range of water conditions, with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 18 to 25°C (64 to 77°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal for Green Torpedo Snails. Ensure the filter provides adequate water movement without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Green Torpedo Snails are scavengers and will consume algae, detritus, and uneaten food. Supplement their diet with blanched vegetables like spinach and cucumber, and provide sinking algae wafers as needed.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Green Torpedo Snails are peaceful and can be kept with a variety of community fish. Suitable tank mates include tetras, guppies, and peaceful invertebrates like shrimp.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Green Torpedo Snails are non-aggressive and spend much of their time scavenging for food. They are known for their ability to close their operculum (trapdoor) to protect themselves from predators.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive fish or those that prey on snails, such as certain loaches and pufferfish.

name: Giant Tower Cap Snail (Brotia herculea)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Giant Tower Cap Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Tylomelania sp.
    • Common name: Giant Tower Cap Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Sulawesi, Indonesia
    • Adult size: 8-12 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 7 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Giant Tower Cap Snails thrive in tanks with a soft, sandy substrate that allows them to move easily without damaging their shells.
    • A minimum tank size of 40L is recommended due to their large size, and larger tanks are preferable for multiple snails.
    • Provide plenty of hard surfaces, such as rocks and driftwood, for grazing, and maintain low to moderate lighting to replicate their natural environment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5 to support shell health.
    • Maintain a warm water temperature between 24 to 30°C (75 to 86°F) as they originate from tropical regions.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable, allowing the snails to graze without strong currents disrupting their movement.
    • Ensure high water quality, as Giant Tower Cap Snails are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • These snails are omnivores, primarily feeding on algae, biofilm, and detritus within the tank.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables like cucumber and spinach for a balanced diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Giant Tower Cap Snails are peaceful and can be housed with other non-aggressive tank mates, such as small fish, shrimp, and snails.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or snail-eating fish, including certain loaches and cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • These snails are generally calm and spend most of their time grazing on surfaces, helping to keep the tank clean.
    • They reproduce slowly in aquariums, so there is typically no concern of overpopulation.

name: White Giant Tower Cap Snail (Brotia herculea)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping White Giant Tower Cap Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Tylomelania sp.
    • Common name: White Giant Tower Cap Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Sulawesi, Indonesia
    • Adult size: 8-12 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 7 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • White Giant Tower Cap Snails thrive in tanks with a soft, sandy substrate to allow easy movement and to prevent shell damage.
    • A minimum tank size of 40L is recommended due to their large size, with additional space for multiple snails.
    • Provide ample hard surfaces like rocks and driftwood for grazing, and maintain low to moderate lighting to suit their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails require slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5 to support shell health.
    • Maintain a warm temperature between 24 to 30°C (75 to 86°F) to replicate their tropical environment.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, allowing the snails to graze comfortably without disturbance.
    • High water quality is crucial, as White Giant Tower Cap Snails are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • These snails are omnivores and primarily consume algae, biofilm, and detritus found on surfaces within the tank.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables like spinach and zucchini for balanced nutrition.

  6. Tank mates:

    • White Giant Tower Cap Snails are peaceful and can be housed with non-aggressive tank mates like small fish, shrimp, and other snails.
    • Avoid housing them with aggressive or snail-eating fish such as loaches and certain cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • These snails are calm and spend most of their time grazing, contributing to the cleanliness of the tank.
    • They reproduce slowly in aquariums, so overpopulation is usually not a concern.

name: Triangle Rabbit Snail (Tylomelania sinobartfeldi)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Triangle Rabbit Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Tylomelania sp.
    • Common name: Triangle Rabbit Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Sulawesi, Indonesia
    • Adult size: 4-6 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Triangle Rabbit Snails prefer a soft, sandy substrate that allows them to move easily without damaging their shell.
    • A tank size of at least 30L is recommended to provide space for exploration and foraging.
    • Provide hard surfaces like rocks and driftwood for grazing, and maintain low to moderate lighting to replicate their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails thrive in slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5, which helps maintain their shell health.
    • Maintain a warm temperature between 24 to 30°C (75 to 86°F), as they originate from tropical regions.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, allowing the snails to graze comfortably without strong currents.
    • Keep the water quality high, as Triangle Rabbit Snails are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • Triangle Rabbit Snails are omnivores and primarily feed on biofilm, algae, and detritus within the tank.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables like spinach or zucchini for balanced nutrition.

  6. Tank mates:

    • These snails are peaceful and can be housed with other non-aggressive tank mates like small fish, shrimp, and snails.
    • Avoid housing them with aggressive or snail-eating fish such as loaches and certain cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Triangle Rabbit Snails are calm and spend most of their time grazing on surfaces, helping keep the tank clean.
    • They reproduce slowly in aquariums, so overpopulation is typically not a concern.

name: Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snail (Faunus ater)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Faunus ater
    • Common name: Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, commonly found in brackish and freshwater environments
    • Adult size: 4-6 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snails prefer tanks with a sandy or fine gravel substrate, allowing them to burrow and move easily.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is suitable, though larger tanks are preferred if housing multiple snails.
    • They appreciate a stable, low to moderate lighting environment with hard surfaces like rocks and driftwood for grazing.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails thrive in slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5 to support shell health.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).
    • They can adapt to freshwater but also do well in low-salinity brackish water environments.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, as it allows the snails to graze and explore without disruption.
    • High water quality is essential; they are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snails are omnivores, primarily feeding on detritus, biofilm, and algae within the aquarium.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables like zucchini and cucumber for balanced nutrition.

  6. Tank mates:

    • These snails are peaceful and can coexist with non-aggressive tank mates, including small fish, shrimp, and other snails.
    • Avoid housing them with aggressive or snail-eating fish like certain loaches and pufferfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Cappuccino Devil Thorn Snails are calm and spend most of their time burrowing or grazing on tank surfaces, contributing to a clean environment.
    • They reproduce slowly and typically do not breed in standard freshwater aquariums, so overpopulation is not a concern.

name: Wild Apple Snail (Pomacea sp)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Wild Apple Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Pomacea maculata or Pomacea canaliculata
    • Common name: Wild Apple Snail
    • Family: Ampullariidae
    • Origin: South America
    • Adult size: 5-15 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Wild Apple Snails prefer tanks with ample space and a soft substrate, like sand or smooth gravel, to accommodate their size and allow for easy movement.
    • A minimum tank size of 40L is recommended for a single adult, with larger tanks needed for multiple snails.
    • They require access to the water surface for breathing, so maintain a gap between the water level and tank lid.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These snails thrive in neutral to slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0 to support shell health.
    • Maintain a temperature range of 20 to 28°C (68 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, allowing the snails to navigate and feed without being disturbed by strong currents.
    • Ensure high water quality, as Wild Apple Snails are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels, which can harm their health.

  5. Diet:

    • Wild Apple Snails are omnivores and will consume a variety of foods, including algae, plant matter, and detritus.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, blanched vegetables, and occasional protein-based foods like shrimp pellets for balanced nutrition.
    • Note: They may consume live plants, so this should be considered if kept in a planted aquarium.

  6. Tank mates:

    • These snails are generally peaceful and compatible with most community fish, such as tetras, guppies, and corydoras catfish.
    • Avoid housing them with aggressive, snail-eating fish like certain loaches and pufferfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Wild Apple Snails are active and often seen exploring the tank or grazing on surfaces, contributing to tank cleanliness.
    • They can reproduce prolifically in aquariums, laying eggs above the waterline, so monitor and remove egg clusters if overpopulation is a concern.

name: Wild Type Axolotl (Ambystoma mexicanum)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Wild Type Axolotl

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Axolotl
    • Common name: Wild Type Axolotl
    • Family: Ambystomatidae
    • Origin: Mexico, specifically the Lake Xochimilco and Lake Chalco regions
    • Adult length: Varies, typically between 15 to 45 cm
    • Lifespan: Up to 15 years with proper care

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Wild Type Axolotls require a spacious tank with ample floor space for movement. A minimum tank size of 20 gallons per axolotl is recommended.
    • Provide hiding spots with rocks, caves, and aquatic plants like Java Moss or Anubias. Avoid gravel substrate as axolotls can ingest it, leading to health issues.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature cool, ideally between 16 to 20°C (60 to 68°F).
    • Maintain good water quality with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5 and low ammonia and nitrate levels.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Avoid strong water currents as axolotls are poor swimmers. Use a gentle filtration system to maintain water quality without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed Wild Type Axolotls a diet primarily consisting of live or frozen foods like bloodworms, blackworms, brine shrimp, and earthworms.
    • Offer occasional treats of high-quality axolotl pellets or sinking carnivore pellets.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Axolotls are best kept alone or with their own kind to prevent potential aggression or stress.
    • Do not house axolotls with fast-moving or nippy fish as they may mistake their appendages for food and attempt to bite them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Wild Type Axolotls are primarily nocturnal and may become stressed in brightly lit tanks. Provide subdued lighting and plenty of hiding places to make them feel secure.
    • They are generally peaceful towards tank mates of appropriate size and temperament but should be monitored for any signs of aggression.
