name: UK Bred Montezuma Swordtail (Xiphophorus montezumae) 3-4cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Montezuma Swordtail Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus montezumae
    • Common name: Montezuma Swordtail
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Mexico
    • Adult length: 7 to 10 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Montezuma Swordtails prefer a well-decorated tank with hiding spots and open swimming areas. A minimum tank size of 75L is suitable for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide live or artificial plants, rocks, and driftwood for shelter and territory establishment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Montezuma Swordtails thrive in slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Choose a filter with a gentle to moderate flow, as Montezuma Swordtails do not prefer strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Montezuma Swordtails are omnivores, and their diet should include high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple.
    • Include live or frozen foods like brine shrimp, daphnia, and bloodworms to provide variety and essential nutrients.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Montezuma Swordtails are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as tetras, livebearers, and non-aggressive cichlids.
    • Avoid housing them with fin-nipping or aggressive fish to prevent stress and injuries.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Montezuma Swordtails are active swimmers, and males may display territorial behavior. Keep them in a ratio of females to males to reduce aggression.
    • They generally coexist well with other community fish but monitor for signs of aggression and adjust stocking if necessary.

name: Assorted Sailfin Molly (Poecilia latipinna)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Sailfin Molly Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia latipinna
    • Common name: Sailfin Molly
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Coastal brackish and marine waters of North and Central America
    • Adult length: 5 to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Sailfin Mollies prefer a spacious tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 75 litres is recommended for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide ample hiding places and areas with dense vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate plants like Java Moss, Hornwort, and Vallisneria.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Sailfin Mollies thrive in slightly alkaline to brackish water conditions with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Sailfin Mollies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple.
    • Supplement their diet with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and algae-based foods to provide essential nutrients and mimic their natural diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Sailfin Mollies are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as other mollies, platies, swordtails, and peaceful tetras.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping fish species that may intimidate or harass them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Sailfin Mollies are active swimmers and display social behavior, especially in groups.
    • They are generally peaceful but may exhibit some territorial behavior, especially during breeding.

name: Yellow Convict Cichlid (Amatitlania nanolutea) 3-4cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Yellow Convict Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Amatitlania nanolutea
    • Common name: Yellow Convict Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America (Honduras, Costa Rica)
    • Adult length: 12 cm
    • Lifespan: 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Yellow Convict Cichlids prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots and territories. A minimum tank size of 75 gallons is recommended.
    • Provide rocks, caves, and driftwood to mimic their natural habitat. They also appreciate plants like Java Fern and Anubias.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 20 to 25°C (68 to 77°F).
    • Maintain a pH level between 6.5 to 8.0.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Yellow Convict Cichlids are tolerant of various water flow conditions but ensure adequate filtration to keep the water clean.

  5. Diet:

    • They are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet of high-quality pellets or flakes supplemented with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Yellow Convict Cichlids are territorial and may be aggressive towards other fish, especially during breeding. They are best kept with other robust and similarly sized cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • They exhibit typical cichlid behavior, including digging and rearranging substrate. Avoid keeping them with timid or small fish that may become targets of aggression.

name: Blackbanded Sunfish (Enneacanthus chaetodon)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Blackbanded Sunfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Enneacanthus chaetodon
    • Common name: Blackbanded Sunfish
    • Family: Centrarchidae
    • Origin: Eastern United States
    • Adult length: Approximately 6 inches
    • Lifespan: 4 to 6 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Blackbanded Sunfish prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots such as rocks, caves, and plants. A tank size of at least 30 gallons is recommended.
    • Provide a sandy substrate and driftwood to mimic their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain water temperature between 65°F to 75°F (18°C to 24°C).
    • Water pH should be neutral to slightly acidic, ideally between 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a filtration system appropriate for the size of the tank to maintain water quality.
    • Blackbanded Sunfish prefer gentle water flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Offer a varied diet including high-quality pellets, flakes, and live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Blackbanded Sunfish are territorial and may not tolerate other fish of the same species. They are best kept alone or with other peaceful species such as small tetras or rasboras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Blackbanded Sunfish are generally peaceful but can be aggressive towards tankmates, especially during breeding season.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots to reduce aggression and territorial behavior.

name: False Yellow Jacket Cichlid (Parachromis motaguensis)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping False Yellow Jacket Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Parachromis motaguensis
    • Common name: False Yellow Jacket Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America, specifically Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica
    • Adult length: Up to 30 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • False Yellow Jacket Cichlids require a large tank with a minimum size of 300L due to their size and territorial behavior.
    • Include hiding spots and caves made of rocks or driftwood to provide territories and shelters for each fish.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water parameters stable with a pH between 7.0 to 8.0 and a temperature range of 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • They prefer slightly hard water with a moderate current.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a powerful filtration system as these fish are messy eaters and produce a lot of waste.
    • Aim for a strong water flow to mimic their natural habitat, but ensure it's not too strong to stress the fish.

  5. Diet:

    • False Yellow Jacket Cichlids are carnivorous and require a protein-rich diet.
    • Offer a variety of foods including high-quality pellets, live or frozen foods like bloodworms, shrimp, and small fish.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are territorial and aggressive, especially during breeding, so choose tank mates carefully.
    • Compatible tank mates include large, robust cichlids from the same region or other fish that can hold their own against aggression.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • False Yellow Jacket Cichlids are territorial and can be aggressive, especially when breeding.
    • Keep them in pairs or groups with plenty of space and hiding spots to reduce aggression.

name: Honduran Red Point Cichlid (Amatitlania siquia)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Honduran Red Point Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Amatitlania siquia
    • Common name: Honduran Red Point Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America, specifically from Honduras, Guatemala, and Nicaragua
    • Adult length: 15 cm (6 inches)
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Honduran Red Point Cichlids require a tank of at least 30 gallons, but larger tanks are recommended for breeding pairs or communities.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots with rocks, caves, and driftwood, as well as open areas for swimming.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Honduran Red Point Cichlids prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 75 to 82°F (24 to 28°C).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Ensure good filtration to maintain water quality, as they are sensitive to poor water conditions.
    • They tolerate moderate water flow well.

  5. Diet:

    • Honduran Red Point Cichlids are omnivores and accept a variety of foods including pellets, flakes, frozen, and live foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.
    • Offer a varied diet to ensure their health and vibrant coloration.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Honduran Red Point Cichlids can be territorial, especially during breeding, so choose tank mates carefully.
    • Compatible tank mates include robust fish species such as other cichlids of similar size, robust tetras, barbs, and catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Honduran Red Point Cichlids are known for their colorful appearance and relatively peaceful demeanor compared to some other cichlid species.
    • They can be kept in pairs or groups, but aggression may increase during breeding.

name: Hong Kong Pleco (Beaufortia kweichowensis)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Hong Kong Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Beaufortia kweichowensis
    • Common name: Hong Kong Pleco
    • Family: Balitoridae
    • Origin: Hong Kong, China
    • Adult length: Varies, typically 10 to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Hong Kong Plecos require a tank with plenty of hiding spots and smooth surfaces. Provide rocks, driftwood, and caves to create hiding places.
    • Ensure the tank has a strong filtration system and regular water changes to maintain water quality.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).
    • Maintain a pH level between 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a filter that provides gentle to moderate water flow, as Hong Kong Plecos prefer calmer waters.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed a varied diet consisting of sinking pellets, algae wafers, and blanched vegetables such as zucchini and cucumber.
    • Occasionally offer protein-rich foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp as a treat.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Hong Kong Plecos are generally peaceful but may be territorial. Avoid keeping them with aggressive or large fish species.
    • Compatible tank mates include peaceful community fish such as tetras, rasboras, and smaller cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Hong Kong Plecos are nocturnal and will be more active during the night.
    • Provide hiding spots and ensure the tank has subdued lighting to make them feel secure.

name: Indian Mud Moray Eel (Gymnothorax Tile)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Indian Mud Moray Eel Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Gymnothorax tile
    • Common name: Indian Mud Moray Eel
    • Family: Muraenidae
    • Origin: Indian subcontinent, Southeast Asia
    • Adult length: Up to 1 meter (3.3 feet)
    • Lifespan: Up to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Indian Mud Moray Eels prefer a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots like caves, rocks, and PVC pipes.
    • Provide a sand substrate to mimic their natural habitat, as they like to burrow and hide in the substrate.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Indian Mud Moray Eels thrive in tropical freshwater to brackish water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Adequate filtration is essential to maintain water quality, but ensure the filter intake is covered to prevent the eel from getting trapped.

  5. Diet:

    • Indian Mud Moray Eels are carnivorous and feed on a diet of live or frozen meaty foods like fish, shrimp, squid, and crustaceans.
    • Feed them 2-3 times a week, offering appropriately sized portions to prevent overfeeding.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Indian Mud Moray Eels are solitary and aggressive towards other fish, so it's best to keep them alone in the tank.
    • Avoid keeping them with smaller fish or those with long fins, as they may be seen as prey.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Indian Mud Moray Eels are nocturnal and primarily active at night, spending much of their time hiding in caves or burrowed in the substrate during the day.
    • They are not suitable for community tanks due to their aggressive nature and predatory behavior.

name: Zebra Acara Cichlid (Ivanacara adoketa)

Our Guide To Keeping Zebra Acara Cichlid Fish

    • Scientific name: Ivanacara adoketa

    • Zebra Acara Cichlids prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots and areas for exploration. Decorate the tank with rocks, driftwood, and plants to mimic their natural habitat.

    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F) and maintain a pH level between 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Aim for moderate filtration to maintain water quality, and ensure gentle to moderate water flow to mimic their natural environment.

  5. Diet:

    • Zebra Acara Cichlids are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including high-quality pellets, flakes, and live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and small insects.

    • They can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size and temperament, such as tetras, rasboras, and small catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Zebra Acara Cichlids are relatively peaceful cichlids but may exhibit territorial behavior, especially during breeding. Provide adequate space and hiding spots to reduce aggression.

name: Topaz Cichlid (Amatitlania myrnae) 3-4cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Topaz Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Amatitlania myrnae
    • Common name: Topaz Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Central America (specifically Honduras)
    • Adult length: 6 inches (15 centimeters)
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Topaz Cichlids require a tank size of at least 30 gallons for a pair.
    • Decorate the tank with caves, rocks, and driftwood to create hiding spots and territories.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 75 to 82°F (24 to 28°C).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide efficient filtration to maintain water quality.

name: Redtail Blue Loach (Yasuhikotakia modesta)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Redtail Blue Loach Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Yasuhikotakia modesta
    • Common name: Redtail Blue Loach
    • Family: Cobitidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including Thailand and Malaysia
    • Adult length: Up to 12 cm
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Redtail Blue Loaches prefer a well-planted aquarium with hiding spots and caves. Provide a substrate of sand or fine gravel.
    • Include driftwood and rocks to mimic their natural habitat, and ensure the tank has moderate lighting.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle to moderate filter to provide suitable water flow without causing stress to the Redtail Blue Loaches.

  5. Diet:

    • Redtail Blue Loaches are omnivores and accept a varied diet. Include high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Redtail Blue Loaches are peaceful and can be kept with other community fish. They do well with similarly sized and non-aggressive species.
    • Avoid keeping them with fin-nipping or aggressive tank mates.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Redtail Blue Loaches are social and should be kept in groups of at least five individuals to promote natural behaviors.
    • They may display playful behavior and appreciate a well-decorated tank with hiding spots.

name: Snow White Bristlenose Catfish 3cm  (Ancistrus sp.)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Snow White Bristlenose Catfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Ancistrus sp.
    • Common name: Snow White Bristlenose Catfish
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America, Amazon Basin
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Snow White Bristlenose Catfish prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots such as caves, driftwood, and dense vegetation.
    • They appreciate a soft substrate like sand or fine gravel.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Snow White Bristlenose Catfish thrive in tropical water conditions with a temperature range of 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for Common Bristlenose Catfish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Snow White Bristlenose Catfish are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional feedings of live or frozen foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Snow White Bristlenose Catfish are generally peaceful and can be kept with a variety of community fish.
    • They are compatible with other peaceful bottom-dwelling species such as Corydoras catfish and small tetras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Snow White Bristlenose Catfish are primarily nocturnal and will be more active during the evening and night.
    • They are territorial towards their own species, so it's best to keep them singly or in mated pairs unless you have a large enough tank to accommodate multiple individuals.

name: Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish (Pterophyllum scalare)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Pterophyllum scalare
    • Common name: Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 years or more

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish require a tall tank with a capacity of at least 200L to accommodate their vertical swimming behavior.
    • Provide tall plants like Amazon Sword and Vallisneria for them to hide among, and leave open swimming spaces in the middle and upper parts of the tank.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide gentle to moderate water flow with a suitable filter to maintain water quality without causing excessive disturbance.

  5. Diet:

    • Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food supplemented with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish are generally peaceful but can be territorial during breeding. They are compatible with other peaceful community fish such as tetras, rasboras, gouramis, and corydoras catfish.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or very small fish that they may see as prey.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Bulgarian Seal Point Angelfish are known for their graceful swimming and striking appearance, making them a popular choice for community tanks.
    • They may exhibit some aggression during breeding, so provide ample hiding spots and tank space if breeding is intended.

name: L183 Starlight Bristlenose Pleco (Ancistrus dolichopterus) 3cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Starlight Bristlenose Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Ancistrus dolichopterus
    • Common name: Starlight Bristlenose Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: 12 cm (male), 15 cm (female)
    • Lifespan: 5 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Starlight Bristlenose Plecos require a tank with hiding places like caves, driftwood, and rocks.
    • Provide plenty of surfaces for algae growth as they feed on biofilm and algae.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 30°C (75 to 86°F).
    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Water hardness should be between 5 to 15 dGH.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Efficient filtration is necessary to maintain water quality, as they are sensitive to poor water conditions.
    • Provide gentle to moderate water flow to mimic their natural habitat.

  5. Diet:

    • Starlight Bristlenose Plecos are omnivores and primarily herbivorous.
    • Offer a varied diet including high-quality sinking algae wafers, blanched vegetables like zucchini and cucumber, and occasional protein-rich foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with a variety of community fish including tetras, rasboras, peaceful barbs, and other small catfish species.
    • Avoid aggressive or territorial tank mates that may harass them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Starlight Bristlenose Plecos are nocturnal and will be more active during the night.
    • They are peaceful and can coexist with other tank inhabitants.

name: Solarmeter 6.5 UV Index Radiometer
description:
The Solarmeter 6.5 UV Index Radiometer is a compact, handheld device which helps you understand the UVB levels within your reptile's enclosure.
All UV light sources gradually lose output as they get older but this easy to use device will let you know when your UV tube needs to be replaced for a new one.
For animals to thrive, it is important to have areas within their enclosure where they can access UVB in varying strengths as well as be without.
Instructions for Use: Aim the sensor window located on the top panel of the meter directly at the UV source. Press and hold the push-button switch on the face of the meter. For best results take note of the distance the reading was taken from the UV source in order to ensure accurate repeatable results.

name: ProRep Hemp Bedding 10 Litre
description: This Bedding is a soft, fibrous substrate that is suitable for many species of snakes, tortoises or mammals. Highly absorbent, dust free and odourless it is 100% natural and biodegradable.

description: This Bedding is a soft, fibrous substrate that is suitable for many species of snakes, tortoises or mammals. Highly absorbent, dust free and odourless it is 100% natural and biodegradable.

description: This Bedding is a soft, fibrous substrate that is suitable for many species of snakes, tortoises or mammals. Highly absorbent, dust free and odourless it is 100% natural and biodegradable.

name: ProRep Corn Cob Substrate 10 Litre
description: ProRep Corn Cob substrate can be used for many species of lizards and snakes originating from arid habitats. It is made from the centre of corn on the cob ground into a free-flowing granular substrate, which should not be used wet. Care should be taken to avoid significant ingestion of this product.

name: ProRep Aspen Snake Bedding 10 Litre
description: ProRep Aspen Bedding is suitable for snakes, some lizards, birds and small mammals. It is soft, dust-free, odourless and highly absorbent and is made from non-toxic shredded wood sourced from sustainable forests. Spot-clean daily and completely replace every two or three weeks, or more frequently if it becomes heavily soiled or wet. If you are using an under-tank heatmat as your heat source do not use a thick layer of Aspen as this may cause the heatmat to overheat. Please refer to the heatmat manufacturer instructions for more information.

Please refer to the heatmat manufacturer instructions for more information.

name: ProRep Aspen Snake Bedding 14.5kg
description: ProRep Aspen Bedding is suitable for snakes, some lizards, birds and small mammals. Spot-clean daily and completely replace every two or three weeks, or more frequently if it becomes heavily soiled or wet. If you are using an under-tank heatmat as your heat source do not use a thick layer of Aspen as this may cause the heatmat to overheat. Please refer to the heatmat manufacturer instructions for more information.

name: ProRep Tortoise Life Substrate 10 Litre
description: ProRep Tortoise Life is part of the species-specific life series of substrates and has been created to meet the needs of tortoises originating from arid habitats, particularly Mediterranean and Russian tortoises. It is a blend of ingredients that provides the ideal mix of texture and moisture retention to simulate the soils found in their natural habitats. The addition of pure limestone to the mix provides additional calcium if the substrate is eaten. It is also suitable for many species of lizards that originate from arid habitats. Spot-clean daily to remove soiled substrate and replace completely every 2 or 3 weeks. Areas of the substrate can be sprayed to provide local humidity but avoid making the substrate too wet.

name: ProRep Coco Brick 150g
description:
An expandable reptile substrate that soaks in water and becomes a moist bedding for reptiles and also amphibians. Made from natural sustainable coconut husk, The dry brick expands by 800% and also holds many times its own weight in water. Highly absorbent of waste as well which also makes spot cleaning easy for you.
Perfect for tree frogs, chameleons, crested geckos and also salamanders.

name: ProRep Coco Brick 650g
description:
An expandable reptile substrate that soaks in water and becomes a moist bedding for reptiles and also amphibians. Made from natural sustainable coconut husk, The dry brick expands by 800% and also holds many times its own weight in water.
Highly absorbent of waste as well which also makes spot cleaning easy for you. Perfect for tree frogs, chameleons, crested geckos and also salamanders.

name: ProRep Tortoise Life Bio Substrate 10 Litre
description: ProRep Tortoise Life is part of the species-specific series of substrates and has been created to meet the needs of Tortoises originating from dry habitats, particularly Mediterranean and Russian Tortoises. It is a blend of professional quality loam, soft fine sand and coconut husk that provides the ideal mix of texture and moisture retention, simulating the soils found in their natural habitats. The addition of coconut husk allows for a lighter substrate without the mineral content, increasing the organic material in the mix provides peace of mind if accidently ingested. It is also suitable for many species of lizards that originate from similar habitats. Directions: Spread the substrate evenly over the bottom of the enclosure to a depth of at least 15cm) or more for mature animals. Russian tortoises particularly may need a deeper substrate as they burrow extensively. Spot-clean daily to remove soiled substrate and replace completely every 2 or 3 weeks. Areas of the substrate can be sprayed to keep it slightly damp and so provide local humidity, but avoid making the substrate too wet.

name: ProRep Beardie Life Substrate 10kg
description: ProRep Beardie Life is part of the species specific series of substrates and has been designed to meet the needs of Bearded Dragons and other desert species. In the wild there are few species that actually live on pure sand and so Beardie Life has been designed to mimic the sandy soil more typical of desert habitats. Beardie Life contains a mixture of sand and soil to create a realistic looking and feeling substrate which encourages natural behaviour, such as digging and foraging, and which aids the maintenance of a suitable environment. The addition of soil to the mixture reduces the risk of impaction sometimes seen with pure sand, while enhancing the moisture retention ability of the substrate.

name: ProRep Straw Tortoise Bedding 10 Litre
description: ProRep Straw Bedding can be used for tortoises as well as many other large snakes and lizards that originate from arid habitats. It is made from compressed straw pellets to provide a soft bedding that should not cause impaction if eaten. Directions: Spread the substrate evenly over the bottom of the enclosure to a depth of at least2.5-5cm. Spot-clean daily and completely replace every two or three weeks, or more frequently if it becomes heavily soiled or wet. This substrate should not be used wet. If you are using an under-tank heatmat as your heat source do not use a thick layer of Straw Bedding as this may cause the heatmat to overheat. Please refer to the heatmat manufacturer instructions for more information.

name: ProRep Straw Tortoise Bedding 25 Litre
description: ProRep Straw Bedding can be used for tortoises as well as many other large snakes and lizards that originate from arid habitats. It is made from compressed straw pellets to provide a soft bedding that should not cause impaction if eaten. Directions: Spread the substrate evenly over the bottom of the enclosure to a depth of at least 2.5-5cm. Spot-clean daily and completely replace every two or three weeks, or more frequently if it becomes heavily soiled or wet. This substrate should not be used wet. If you are using an under-tank heatmat as your heat source do not use a thick layer of Straw Bedding as this may cause the heatmat to overheat. Please refer to the heatmat manufacturer instructions for more information.

name: ProRep Snake Life Lignocel Substrate 10 litre
description: ProRep Snake Life is part of the series of substrates designed for use for specific animal species or types. Manufactured under the brand name Lignocel specifically to meet the needs of snakes. Snake Life is produced from wood sourced from sustainable forests and has a low dust and resinous oils content. Dried at a high temperature, it is safe for use for many species of snake that do not need high humidity environments. It is highly absorbent and will quickly absorb water spillages or animal waste helping to trap any unwanted odours and making spot cleaning quick and easy.

name: Assorted Ghost Koi Carp 11-13cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Ghost Koi Carp Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Cyprinus carpio
    • Common name: Ghost Koi Carp
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: United Kingdom (hybrid of Common Carp and Metallic Ogon Koi)
    • Adult length: 60 to 90 cm (can exceed 100 cm in ideal conditions)
    • Lifespan: 20 to 30 years (some may live longer with excellent care)
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful but bold

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Ghost Koi are best suited for large, well-filtered garden ponds. A minimum of 1500L is recommended, with more space for multiple individuals.
    • Provide plenty of open swimming areas along with natural features like aquatic plants, rocks, and shaded zones.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH between 6.8 and 8.0.
    • Ideal water temperature range is 15 to 25°C (59 to 77°F). They can tolerate a wide range of temperatures if acclimated properly.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a high-quality pond filtration system to manage their large bioload and maintain clear, oxygenated water.
    • Gentle to moderate water flow is preferred, with supplemental aeration from air stones or waterfalls.

  5. Diet:

    • Offer a balanced diet of high-quality koi pellets formulated for growth and coloration.
    • Supplement with fresh vegetables (like peas and lettuce), fruits (like watermelon), and protein sources such as earthworms, silkworms, or bloodworms.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Ghost Koi are peaceful and can be kept with other koi varieties, large goldfish, golden orfe, and tench.
    • Do not house them with aggressive fish or small species that may be outcompeted or injured.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Ghost Koi are known for being more robust and less shy than traditional koi, often approaching humans during feeding time.
    • They are social, enjoy the company of their own kind, and thrive in groups in a calm pond environment.

name: Gold Tench 2-3" (Tinca tinca)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Gold Tench Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Tinca tinca (golden variety)
    • Common name: Gold Tench
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Selectively bred from the wild Green Tench (native to Europe and western Asia)
    • Adult length: 30 to 60 cm
    • Lifespan: 15 to 20 years (some may live longer with excellent conditions)
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful and shy

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Gold Tench thrive in large, natural-style garden ponds with a soft substrate and dense plant cover.
    • Include submerged and floating plants, and ensure shaded areas to provide a sense of security.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Ideal pH range is 6.5 to 8.0.
    • They prefer cooler water, typically between 10 to 24°C (50 to 75°F), and can overwinter in ponds that don’t freeze solid.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use an efficient pond filter to maintain water clarity and oxygenation, especially in warm weather.
    • Gentle water flow is ideal, as they naturally inhabit slow-moving waters.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed sinking pond pellets as a staple diet. They also enjoy live or frozen foods like bloodworms, tubifex, and chopped earthworms.
    • Supplement with vegetable matter such as blanched spinach or peas.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Gold Tench do well with other peaceful pond fish such as koi, goldfish, golden orfe, and green tench.
    • Avoid fast, aggressive feeders that might outcompete them for food at the bottom of the pond.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Gold Tench are bottom-dwelling, slow-moving fish that prefer foraging in groups. They are more active in the early morning and evening.
    • They are very peaceful and non-aggressive, making them ideal for calm community pond settings.

name: Green Tench 2-3" (Tinca tinca)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Green Tench Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Tinca tinca
    • Common name: Green Tench
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Europe and parts of western Asia
    • Adult length: 30 to 60 cm
    • Lifespan: 15 to 20 years (some may live longer)
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful and shy

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Green Tench are best suited for large, natural-style ponds with soft, muddy bottoms where they can forage and burrow.
    • Include areas with aquatic plants, both rooted and floating, as well as plenty of shaded and covered spots for hiding.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH between 6.5 and 8.0.
    • Ideal temperature range is 10 to 24°C (50 to 75°F), though they are cold-tolerant and can overwinter in temperate climates.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a pond filter suitable for moderate bioload, as Tench are not particularly messy but do stir the substrate while foraging.
    • Gentle water flow is preferred, mimicking the calm waters of lakes and slow-moving rivers.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed a mix of sinking pond pellets and natural foods such as worms, insect larvae, crustaceans, and plant matter.
    • Tench are bottom-feeders and prefer food that sinks. Occasional treats like bloodworms or chopped earthworms are appreciated.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Green Tench are compatible with other peaceful pond fish like koi, goldfish, and orfe.
    • They are non-aggressive and can coexist with a variety of species, though they may be outcompeted by faster feeders if not given adequate food.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Green Tench are bottom-dwellers that tend to be shy and secretive, especially during the day. They are more active at dusk and dawn.
    • Best kept in groups of 2 or more for social comfort. They will often forage through the substrate and hide under vegetation.

name: Mirror Carp 2-3" (Cyprinus carpio)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Mirror Carp Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Cyprinus carpio
    • Common name: Mirror Carp
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Eurasia (Domesticated variety of Common Carp)
    • Adult length: 60 to 90 cm (can exceed 100 cm in large ponds or lakes)
    • Lifespan: 20 to 40 years (some over 50 years)
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful but robust

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Mirror Carp are best kept in large outdoor ponds or natural lakes. A minimum volume of 2000L is suggested for a small group.
    • Provide a naturalistic environment with mud or gravel substrates, aquatic vegetation, and plenty of space for foraging and swimming.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH between 6.5 and 8.0.
    • Water temperature should be between 10 to 25°C (50 to 77°F). They are hardy and can tolerate a wide range of conditions.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Due to their size and feeding habits, a high-capacity filtration system is essential to maintain water quality.
    • Moderate water flow is ideal, and natural aeration through waterfalls or air pumps is recommended for oxygenation.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed high-quality carp pellets or pond sticks as a staple diet.
    • Supplement with natural foods like worms, insects, aquatic plants, fruits, and grains. They enjoy rooting around the substrate in search of food.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Mirror Carp can be housed with other large, peaceful pond fish such as koi, tench, and golden orfe.
    • Avoid mixing with small or delicate species that could be accidentally injured due to their size and foraging behavior.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Mirror Carp are calm, intelligent fish known for their unique scale patterns and friendly behavior toward keepers.
    • They are social and often feed in groups. Provide plenty of space to avoid overcrowding and ensure proper growth and behavior.

name: Golden Orfe 2-3" (Leuciscus idus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Golden Orfe Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Leuciscus idus (Golden variety)
    • Common name: Golden Orfe
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Europe and western Asia
    • Adult length: 40 to 60 cm
    • Lifespan: 15 to 20 years
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful and active

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Golden Orfe are fast swimmers that require large outdoor ponds rather than indoor tanks. A pond volume of at least 1000L is recommended, with extra space for schooling behavior.
    • Include open swimming areas and some marginal aquatic plants. They prefer clear, well-oxygenated water with plenty of surface movement.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a pH between 6.5 and 8.0.
    • They prefer cool water temperatures between 10 to 20°C (50 to 68°F). Avoid warm, stagnant water conditions.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a high-capacity pond filtration system to manage waste and ensure excellent water quality.
    • Golden Orfe enjoy moderate to strong water flow and high oxygen levels. Surface aeration or waterfalls are beneficial.

  5. Diet:

    • Provide a varied diet including high-quality pond pellets, insects, worms, and plant matter.
    • They will also consume natural foods in the pond such as algae, small crustaceans, and aquatic larvae.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Golden Orfe are schooling fish and should be kept in groups of at least three to five individuals.
    • They are compatible with koi, goldfish, and other large, peaceful pond fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Golden Orfe are very active and social fish that spend much of their time near the surface.
    • They are not aggressive but may startle smaller or slow-moving fish due to their speed and schooling activity.

name: Everglades Pygmy Sunfish Pair (Elassoma evergladei)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Everglades Pygmy Sunfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Elassoma evergladei
    • Common name: Everglades Pygmy Sunfish
    • Family: Elassomatidae
    • Origin: Southeastern United States, particularly found in the Florida Everglades
    • Adult length: Approximately 2.5 cm (1 inch)
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Everglades Pygmy Sunfish thrive in heavily planted tanks with plenty of hiding places. Utilize dense vegetation, driftwood, and rocks to create natural hiding spots.
    • A tank size of 10 gallons or larger is suitable for a small group of Everglades Pygmy Sunfish.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).
    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal for Everglades Pygmy Sunfish. Consider using sponge filters or low-flow filtration systems.

  5. Diet:

    • Everglades Pygmy Sunfish are micropredators and prefer small live or frozen foods such as daphnia, brine shrimp, and micro worms. Offer them a varied diet to ensure proper nutrition.
    • They may also accept high-quality dry foods like micro pellets, but live or frozen foods should be the staple of their diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Due to their small size and peaceful nature, Everglades Pygmy Sunfish are best kept in a species-only tank or with very small, peaceful fish species.
    • They may be housed with other small, non-aggressive fish that occupy different levels of the tank, such as small tetras or rasboras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Everglades Pygmy Sunfish are peaceful and shy fish that prefer to stay near cover or vegetation. They should not be housed with larger or more aggressive fish species that may intimidate them.
    • They are best kept in a quiet tank with minimal disturbances to encourage natural behavior and breeding.

name: 10 x Axolotl Eggs
description:
Male is leucistic and female is melanistic

Our Guide To Keeping Axolotl

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Axolotl
    • Common name: Axolotl
    • Family: Ambystomatidae
    • Origin: Mexico, specifically the Lake Xochimilco and Lake Chalco regions
    • Adult length: Varies, typically between 15 to 45 cm
    • Lifespan: Up to 15 years with proper care

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Axolotls require a spacious tank with ample floor space for movement. A minimum tank size of 20 gallons per axolotl is recommended.
    • Provide hiding spots with rocks, caves, and aquatic plants like Java Moss or Anubias. Avoid gravel substrate as axolotls can ingest it, leading to health issues.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature cool, ideally between 16 to 20°C (60 to 68°F).
    • Maintain good water quality with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5 and low ammonia and nitrate levels.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Avoid strong water currents as axolotls are poor swimmers. Use a gentle filtration system to maintain water quality without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed Axolotls a diet primarily consisting of live or frozen foods like bloodworms, blackworms, brine shrimp, and earthworms.
    • Offer occasional treats of high-quality axolotl pellets or sinking carnivore pellets.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Axolotls are best kept alone or with their own kind to prevent potential aggression or stress.
    • Do not house axolotls with fast-moving or nippy fish as they may mistake their appendages for food and attempt to bite them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Axolotls are primarily nocturnal and may become stressed in brightly lit tanks. Provide subdued lighting and plenty of hiding places to make them feel secure.
    • They are generally peaceful towards tank mates of appropriate size and temperament but should be monitored for any signs of aggression.

name: Emerald Tree Skink ( Dasia Smaragdina ) WC
Mountain Swordtail (Xiphophorus nezahualcoyotl)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Mountain Swordtail Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus nezahualcoyotl
    • Common name: Mountain Swordtail
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America
    • Adult length: 5-6 cm
    • Lifespan: 3-5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Mountain Swordtails prefer a tank with plenty of swimming space and hiding places. A minimum tank size of 40 litres is recommended for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide plants and decorations for hiding and breeding, as well as open areas for swimming.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Mountain Swordtails thrive in slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for Mountain Swordtails, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Mountain Swordtails are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple.
    • Supplement their diet with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia to provide essential nutrients and mimic their natural diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Mountain Swordtails are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful fish species of similar size.
    • They are compatible with other livebearers, tetras, rasboras, and peaceful bottom-dwellers like Corydoras catfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Mountain Swordtails are active swimmers and can be kept in a community tank with other peaceful fish species.
    • They may exhibit some aggression towards conspecifics or other livebearers if the tank is overcrowded, so ensure adequate space and hiding places.

name: L081 Gold Nugget Pleco (Baryancistrus xanthellus) 10-12cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping L081 Gold Nugget Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Baryancistrus xanthellus
    • Common name: Gold Nugget Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: Up to 14 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Gold Nugget Plecos require a tank with plenty of hiding places such as caves, driftwood, and rocks.
    • Provide a substrate of sand or fine gravel to mimic their natural environment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow, ensuring good water quality.

  5. Diet:

    • Gold Nugget Plecos are omnivores and require a varied diet.
    • Offer them a combination of high-quality sinking pellets, algae wafers, and blanched vegetables like zucchini and cucumber.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are generally peaceful but may become territorial towards other bottom-dwelling fish.
    • Compatible tank mates include peaceful community fish that inhabit different areas of the tank.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

name: UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppy Pair (Poecilia reticulata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia reticulata
    • Common name: UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae

    • Lifespan: 1 - 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 10 gallons, but a larger tank around 20 gallons or more is recommended for a community setup.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and plants, as well as open swimming areas. Guppies appreciate live or artificial plants for cover.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppies prefer slightly hard water with a pH range between 7.0 and 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Good filtration is essential for maintaining water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for UK Bred Albino Full Red guppies.

  5. Diet:

    • UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including flake, pellet, and live foods.
    • Offer them a varied diet including high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple, supplemented with occasional treats like bloodworms, brine shrimp, or daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppies are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size. Avoid keeping them with fin-nipping or aggressive species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • UK Bred Albino Full Red Guppies are active and social fish that do best in groups. Keeping them in schools of 6 or more will help reduce stress and encourage natural behaviors.
    • They are generally compatible with other peaceful community fish, but avoid keeping them with larger, aggressive species that may intimidate or prey on them.

name: Blueberry Snail (Viviparus sp)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Blueberry Snails

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Tylomelania gemmifera
    • Common name: Blueberry Snail
    • Family: Pachychilidae
    • Origin: Sulawesi, Indonesia
    • Adult size: 3-5 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Blueberry Snails prefer tanks with sandy or fine gravel substrates and plenty of hard surfaces like rocks and driftwood for grazing and resting.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group of these snails.
    • They thrive in stable, warmer water conditions similar to their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Blueberry Snails require slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.5 to 8.5 to support shell health.
    • Maintain a warmer temperature range of 26 to 30°C (79 to 86°F) to replicate their native tropical environment.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, allowing the snails to move and graze comfortably.
    • Ensure high water quality, as Blueberry Snails are sensitive to nitrates and ammonia levels.

  5. Diet:

    • These snails are omnivores and primarily graze on algae and detritus in the tank.
    • Supplement their diet with algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables such as spinach or zucchini for balanced nutrition.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Blueberry Snails are peaceful and can be housed with small, non-aggressive community fish, shrimp, and other snails.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or snail-eating fish, such as certain loaches or cichlids, that may see them as prey.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • These snails are generally peaceful and spend most of their time grazing on surfaces within the tank, contributing to a clean environment.
    • They reproduce slowly in aquariums, so there is minimal risk of overpopulation.

name: Adult Common Bristlenose Catfish (Ancistrus sp.)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Common Bristlenose Catfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Ancistrus sp.
    • Common name: Common Bristlenose Catfish
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America, Amazon Basin
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Common Bristlenose Catfish prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots such as caves, driftwood, and dense vegetation.
    • They appreciate a soft substrate like sand or fine gravel.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Common Bristlenose Catfish thrive in tropical water conditions with a temperature range of 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).
    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for Common Bristlenose Catfish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Common Bristlenose Catfish are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including algae wafers, sinking pellets, and blanched vegetables.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional feedings of live or frozen foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Common Bristlenose Catfish are generally peaceful and can be kept with a variety of community fish.
    • They are compatible with other peaceful bottom-dwelling species such as Corydoras catfish and small tetras.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Common Bristlenose Catfish are primarily nocturnal and will be more active during the evening and night.
    • They are territorial towards their own species, so it's best to keep them singly or in mated pairs unless you have a large enough tank to accommodate multiple individuals.

name: Longfin Gold Zebra Danio (Danio rerio)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Longfin Gold Zebra Danio Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Danio rerio
    • Common name: Longfin Gold Zebra Danio
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: South Asia, specifically India, Bangladesh, Nepal, and Myanmar
    • Adult length: Up to 4 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 4 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios are active swimmers and require a tank with ample swimming space. A tank size of at least 10 gallons is recommended for a small group.
    • Provide hiding spots and areas with vegetation such as Java Moss and Hornwort to mimic their natural habitat.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios thrive in freshwater with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios prefer gentle water flow, so choose a filter that provides minimal disturbance.

  5. Diet:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios are omnivores and accept various foods including flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.
    • Offer a varied diet to ensure they receive essential nutrients.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as other danios, rasboras, and small catfish.
    • Avoid housing them with fin-nipping or aggressive species that may stress them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Longfin Gold Zebra Danios are social and should be kept in groups of at least six individuals to thrive.
    • They exhibit schooling behavior and feel more secure in a group.

    • They are generally peaceful but avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species.
    • Compatible tank mates include other small, non-aggressive fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Goldbelly Topminnows exhibit schooling behavior, so keep them in groups of at least 6 individuals.
    • They are active swimmers and enjoy exploring all levels of the aquarium.

name: Tequila Splitfin (Zoogoneticus tequila)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Tequila Splitfin Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Zoogoneticus tequila
    • Common name: Tequila Splitfin
    • Family: Goodeidae
    • Origin: Mexico
    • Adult length: 5 to 7 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Tequila Splitfins prefer a tank with hiding spots like caves, rocks, and driftwood. A tank size of 40 litres or more is suitable for a small group.
    • Provide a substrate with fine sand, and include live or artificial plants to create a natural environment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 20 to 24°C (68 to 75°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filtration system to provide clean water without strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Tequila Splitfins are omnivores and accept a varied diet. Offer high-quality flakes, pellets, and supplement with live or frozen foods like brine shrimp and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Tequila Splitfins are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful community fish such as small tetras, livebearers, and peaceful catfish.
    • Avoid aggressive or fin-nipping tank mates to prevent stress.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Tequila Splitfins exhibit social behavior, so it's recommended to keep them in groups of at least 3 individuals.
    • They are generally compatible with other community fish and should not be housed with aggressive species.

name: Barred Splitfin (Chapalichthys encaustus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Barred Splitfin Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Chapalichthys encaustus
    • Common name: Barred Splitfin
    • Family: Goodeidae
    • Origin: Endemic to Mexico
    • Adult length: Up to 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Barred Splitfins are best kept in a tank with a minimum size of 40 litres.
    • Provide hiding spots and decorations to mimic their natural habitat, including rocks, caves, and live plants like Java Moss.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly alkaline water conditions with a pH range of 7.2 to 7.8.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a gentle filtration system to provide adequate water flow without causing stress to the fish.

  5. Diet:

    • Barred Splitfins are omnivores and thrive on a varied diet, including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like brine shrimp and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Barred Splitfins are generally peaceful and can be kept with other small, non-aggressive fish species.
    • Avoid housing them with larger or more aggressive tank mates to prevent conflicts.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Barred Splitfins are social fish and should be kept in groups of at least three individuals.
    • They exhibit interesting behaviors, including courtship displays and the characteristic split in the male's anal fin.

name: Polkadot Splitfin (Chapalichthys peraticus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Polkadot Splitfin Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Chapalichthys peraticus
    • Common name: Polkadot Splitfin
    • Family: Goodeidae
    • Origin: Mexico
    • Adult length: 6.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Polkadot Splitfins prefer a spacious tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 40 litres (10 gallons) is recommended for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide ample hiding places and areas with dense vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate plants like Java Moss, Anubias, and floating plants like Water Sprite.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Polkadot Splitfins thrive in slightly alkaline to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 20 to 25°C (68 to 77°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides adequate circulation without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Polkadot Splitfins are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple.
    • Supplement their diet with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia to provide essential nutrients and mimic their natural diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Polkadot Splitfins are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as livebearers, small tetras, rasboras, and peaceful barbs.
    • They are best kept in a species-specific tank or with other goodeid species to prevent interbreeding.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Polkadot Splitfins are active swimmers and may display minor territorial behavior, especially during breeding.
    • They are generally peaceful but can be aggressive towards conspecifics, particularly during mating.

name: Wild Colombian Guppy (Poecilia reticulata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Wild Colombian Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia reticulata
    • Common name: Wild Colombian Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Northeastern South America
    • Adult length: 2.5 - 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 - 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Wild Colombian Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 10 gallons, but a larger tank around 20 gallons or more is recommended for a community setup.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots and plants, as well as open swimming areas. Guppies appreciate live or artificial plants for cover.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Wild Colombian Guppies prefer slightly hard water with a pH range between 7.0 and 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Good filtration is essential for maintaining water quality, and a gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for Wild Colombian guppies.

  5. Diet:

    • Wild Colombian Guppies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including flake, pellet, and live foods.
    • Offer them a varied diet including high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple, supplemented with occasional treats like bloodworms, brine shrimp, or daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Wild Colombian Guppies are peaceful fish and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size. Avoid keeping them with fin-nipping or aggressive species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Wild Colombian Guppies are active and social fish that do best in groups. Keeping them in schools of 6 or more will help reduce stress and encourage natural behaviors.
    • They are generally compatible with other peaceful community fish, but avoid keeping them with larger, aggressive species that may intimidate or prey on them.

name: Red Whiptail Catfish (L010A) (Rineloricaria sp)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Red Whiptail Catfish (L010A)

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Rineloricaria sp. (L010A)
    • Common name: Red Whiptail Catfish
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 8 to 12 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Red Whiptail Catfish prefer a well-planted aquarium with hiding spots like caves and driftwood.
    • Provide smooth substrates, as they like to sift through the substrate in search of food.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable, and efficient filtration is necessary to maintain water quality.

  5. Diet:

    • Red Whiptail Catfish are omnivores, and they thrive on a diet of sinking pellets, wafers, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other community fish, but avoid aggressive tank mates.
    • Compatible with other peaceful catfish species and community fish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Red Whiptail Catfish are generally peaceful, but they may show some territorial behavior.
    • They can be kept singly or in small groups, but provide enough hiding spaces to reduce stress.

name: Rainbow Snakehead 5cm (Channa bleheri)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Rainbow Snakehead Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Channa bleheri
    • Common name: Rainbow Snakehead
    • Family: Channidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia
    • Adult length: 30 to 50 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Rainbow Snakeheads prefer a spacious tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 300L is recommended for a single adult fish.
    • Provide ample hiding places and areas with dense vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate plants like Java Fern, Anubias, and floating plants like Water Lettuce.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Rainbow Snakeheads thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Rainbow Snakeheads are carnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a diet consisting of high-quality pellets, frozen or live foods like small fish, shrimp, and insects.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional treats like earthworms or mealworms to provide essential nutrients and mimic their natural diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Rainbow Snakeheads are predatory and should be kept alone or with large, robust tank mates that cannot be consumed.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Rainbow Snakeheads are solitary and aggressive towards other fish, including conspecifics. They are best kept alone in a species-only tank.
    • Avoid keeping them with smaller or more docile species that may become prey.

name: Tinfoil Barb (Barbonymus schwanenfeldii)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Tinfoil Barb Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Barbonymus schwanenfeldii
    • Common name: Tinfoil Barb
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, including Indonesia and Malaysia
    • Adult length: Up to 35 cm
    • Lifespan: 8 to 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Tinfoil Barbs need a large tank with a minimum capacity of 300 litres, as they grow quite large.
    • Provide ample open swimming space along with some planted areas. They appreciate hardy plants like Java Fern and Anubias as they may nibble on softer plants.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Tinfoil Barbs prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • They require a strong filtration system due to their messy eating habits and high activity levels. A canister filter or a powerful hang-on-back filter is recommended.

  5. Diet:

    • Tinfoil Barbs are omnivores and have a hearty appetite. Offer them a varied diet including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and chopped vegetables.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Tinfoil Barbs are peaceful but active fish. They can be kept with other large, peaceful fish species such as other barbs, tetras, danios, and larger rasboras.
    • Avoid keeping them with smaller fish that they may consider prey.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Tinfoil Barbs are schooling fish and should be kept in groups of at least 5 to 6 individuals to thrive.
    • They may display some aggression during feeding or mating, so provide plenty of space and hiding spots to minimize territorial disputes.

name: Empire Gudgeon (Hypseleotris compressa)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Empire Gudgeon Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Hypseleotris compressa
    • Common name: Empire Gudgeon
    • Family: Eleotridae
    • Origin: Australia
    • Adult length: Up to 8 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Empire Gudgeons prefer a tank with hiding places like caves and driftwood. A tank size of at least 75L is suitable for a small group.
    • Provide a sandy substrate to mimic their natural environment and include live plants such as Java Moss and Anubias for cover.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is suitable, and a sponge filter or a filter with adjustable flow is recommended.

  5. Diet:

    • Empire Gudgeons are omnivores. Offer a balanced diet of high-quality pellets, flakes, and supplement with live or frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are generally peaceful but can be territorial. Keep them with other small, non-aggressive fish that share similar water requirements.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Empire Gudgeons are active swimmers and may exhibit territorial behavior, especially during breeding. Provide adequate hiding places to reduce aggression.
    • They can coexist with other peaceful community fish, but monitor for any signs of aggression.

name: Transvestite Dwarf Cichlid Pair (Nanochromis transvestitus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Transvestite Dwarf Cichlid Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Nanochromis transvestitus
    • Common name: Transvestite Dwarf Cichlid
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: West Africa, specifically in the Congo River Basin
    • Adult length: 4 - 5 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 - 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Provide a tank with plenty of hiding spots like caves and plants to mimic their natural habitat.
    • These fish prefer subdued lighting, so use floating plants to diffuse light.
    • Ensure the tank has a secure lid as they may jump if startled.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  3. Water Parameters:

    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain good water quality with regular water changes.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide gentle to moderate water flow in the tank.
    • An efficient filtration system is necessary to keep the water clean.

  5. Diet:

    • Feed them a varied diet including high-quality flake or pellet food, supplemented with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful but territorial during breeding, so keep them with similar-sized peaceful species like small tetras, rasboras, and peaceful catfish.
    • Avoid aggressive tank mates that may stress them out.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • They exhibit interesting behaviors and are best kept in pairs or a small group with a single male and multiple females.
    • Provide plenty of hiding spots to reduce aggression among tank mates.

name: Clouded Archerfish (Toxotes blythii)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Clouded Archerfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Toxotes blythii
    • Common name: Clouded Archerfish
    • Family: Toxotidae
    • Origin: Southeast Asia, Australia, and New Guinea
    • Adult length: Up to 20 cm
    • Lifespan: Up to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Clouded Archerfish prefer a spacious tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 100L is recommended for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide ample hiding places and areas with floating vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate plants like Java Moss, Hornwort, and Water Sprite.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Clouded Archerfish thrive in slightly brackish water conditions with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Clouded Archerfish are carnivorous and primarily feed on insects in the wild. Offer them a varied diet consisting of live or frozen foods such as insects, shrimp, and small fish.
    • They may also accept high-quality floating pellets or flakes as part of their diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Clouded Archerfish can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size. However, avoid keeping them with small fish that they may consider prey.
    • They may exhibit aggression towards conspecifics, especially during feeding, so monitor their behavior carefully.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Clouded Archerfish are known for their unique hunting behavior of shooting down insects with water jets from their mouths.
    • They are generally peaceful but can display territorial behavior, especially during breeding.

name: Calico Ranchu Goldfish (Carassius auratus) 7-8cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Calico Ranchu Goldfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Carassius auratus (Ranchu variety)
    • Common name: Calico Ranchu Goldfish
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Selectively bred in China and Japan from wild Prussian carp
    • Adult length: 12–15 cm (4.5–6 inches)
    • Lifespan: 10–15+ years with proper care
    • Diet: Omnivore
    • Care Level: Moderate
    • Temperament: Peaceful

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Tank size: Minimum 75 L for the first Ranchu, plus ~40 L for each additional fish.
    • Layout: Open swimming space with soft sand or rounded gravel. Avoid sharp decorations that may damage their delicate fins or wen (head growth).
    • Plants: Use hardy, goldfish-safe plants like Anubias, Java Fern, or Hornwort. Expect occasional nibbling.
    • Oxygenation: Maintain good aeration with an air stone or spray bar.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Temperature: 18–22 °C (fancies prefer the warmer end of the goldfish range).
    • pH: 7.0–8.0, stable and moderately hard.
    • Quality: Ammonia and nitrite at 0 ppm, nitrate < 20–40 ppm. Large, frequent water changes are essential due to their high waste output.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Filtration: Use a filter rated for at least 6–10× the tank volume per hour. Ensure strong biological filtration.
    • Flow: Keep water movement gentle—Ranchus are slow swimmers and can struggle in strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Staple: High-quality sinking goldfish pellets or gel foods formulated for fancy goldfish.
    • Veg: Offer blanched peas, spinach, kale, or courgette regularly for fibre and digestion.
    • Treats: Frozen or live brine shrimp, daphnia, or bloodworms (in moderation).
    • Tips: Avoid floating foods to reduce risk of gulping air and buoyancy issues.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Best: Other fancy goldfish with similar swimming speeds.
    • Possible: Large, peaceful coolwater fish such as Dojo Loaches in very large aquaria.
    • Avoid: Fast single-tail goldfish, fin-nippers, or small tropical fish that may be eaten.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Behavior: Gentle and slow-moving; may be outcompeted for food by faster tank mates.
    • Social: Enjoys the company of its own kind; best kept in groups of at least two or three.
    • Notes: Due to their rounded body and head growth, Ranchus are less agile and require a calm, obstruction-free environment.

name: Seachem Prime 100ml
description:
As Seachem Prime neutralises chlorine and chloramines, ammonia is formed as a side product, this happens with all dechlorinators. Prime has a unique benefit in that it neutralises the ammonia, but crucially, leaves it available for the tank bacteria to digest.

Also present in tap water are any number of highly toxic heavy metals, which Prime detoxifies and leaves them completely safe.Seachem Prime is non-acidic and will not change the pH

When used during water changes on established tanks, it's unique formula also helps in the reduction of nitrates, often a common problem on older tanks and increasingly a problem in some water areas, even for new systems.

If Seachem prime isused in a marine system, it will not cause the skimmer to either over produce foam or stop the skimming process, a critical factor to take into account for marine use.

The inclusion of essential ions within the formula will naturally encourage the fish to produce excess slime coating, it doesn't simply 'add a coating' to the fish, rather it boosts the fishes own natural defences.

Seachem Prime : dechlorinator, chloramine remover(via breaking the chloramine bond), ammonia detoxifier (but allowing the filter to consume the ammonia, so removing it), binds heavy metals, increases the fishes slime coat, helps with the removal of nitrate, safe for marine use.

The strongest, most complete,most concentrated, cost effective water conditioner currently available.
