name: Twig Catfish (Farlowella vittata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Twig Catfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Farlowella vittata
    • Common name: Twig Catfish
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America (Amazon River basin)
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Twig Catfish prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots and driftwood to mimic their natural habitat. Provide a sandy substrate and avoid sharp decorations to prevent injury.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Twig Catfish thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for Twig Catfish. Choose a filter that provides adequate filtration without creating strong currents.

  5. Diet:

    • Twig Catfish are primarily herbivores. Offer them a diet rich in vegetable matter such as algae wafers, blanched vegetables (zucchini, cucumber), and sinking pellets.
    • Supplement their diet with occasional protein-rich foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, or daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Twig Catfish are peaceful and can be kept with other non-aggressive species that inhabit similar water parameters. Suitable tank mates include peaceful tetras, rasboras, small peaceful cichlids, and other catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Twig Catfish are nocturnal and prefer to hide during the day. Provide plenty of hiding spots among plants and decor to make them feel secure.
    • They are peaceful towards tank mates but may be territorial towards their own kind, especially during breeding.

name: L187b Bulldog Pleco (Chaetostoma formosae)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping L187b Bulldog Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Chaetostoma formosae
    • Common name: Bulldog Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America
    • Adult length: 10-12 cm (4-5 inches)
    • Lifespan: 10-15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Bulldog Plecos require a tank with plenty of hiding places such as caves, driftwood, and rocks.
    • They prefer tanks with slow to moderate water flow and heavily planted areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water temperature between 23-27°C (73-81°F).
    • Water pH should be between 6.5-7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow to mimic their natural habitat.

  5. Diet:

    • Bulldog Plecos are omnivores. Offer them a varied diet including sinking pellets, algae wafers, and blanched vegetables.
    • They also require driftwood in the tank as part of their diet to aid in digestion.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful fish species that share similar water parameters.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or larger tank mates that may intimidate or outcompete them for food.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Bulldog Plecos are nocturnal and will spend most of the day hiding in caves or under driftwood.
    • They are generally peaceful but may become territorial towards their own species or other bottom-dwelling fish.

name: Longfin Cherry Barb (Puntius titteya)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Longfin Cherry Barb Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Puntius titteya
    • Common name: Longfin Cherry Barb
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Sri Lanka
    • Adult length: 5 cm
    • Lifespan: 4 to 6 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Longfin Cherry Barbs thrive in a well-planted tank with open swimming areas. A minimum tank size of 75L is recommended for a small school of these fish.
    • Include fine-leaved plants like Java Moss and provide floating plants to diffuse light and create shaded areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Longfin Cherry Barbs prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Choose a filter with a gentle to moderate flow, as Longfin Cherry Barbs don't appreciate strong currents in the tank.

  5. Diet:

    • Longfin Cherry Barbs are omnivores and accept a varied diet. Provide them with high-quality flakes or pellets as a staple, and supplement with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Longfin Cherry Barbs are peaceful community fish and should be kept in groups of at least six individuals for optimal social behavior.
    • They are compatible with other peaceful community fish such as tetras, rasboras, and small catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Longfin Cherry Barbs are active and social fish, displaying vibrant colors, especially during courtship. They may exhibit mild territorial behavior, so provide adequate hiding spots.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping fish that could stress or harm them.

name: Mini Yellow Freshwater Clam (Corbicula javanicus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Mini Yellow Freshwater Clams

  1. About Species:

    • Scientific name: Corbicula javanicus
    • Common name: Mini Yellow Freshwater Clam
    • Family: Cyrenidae
    • Origin: Asia, primarily found in river systems
    • Adult size: 1-3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Mini Yellow Freshwater Clams thrive in tanks with fine sand or smooth gravel substrates, allowing them to burrow partially.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group of clams to provide sufficient space for natural filtration activity.
    • Keep the tank environment stable, with minimal substrate disturbance to avoid stress to the clams.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • These clams prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0 for optimal shell health.
    • Maintain a temperature range of 20 to 26°C (68 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is ideal, as clams rely on water movement to bring in food particles for filtration.
    • Keep water quality high, as clams are sensitive to high ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • Mini Yellow Freshwater Clams are filter feeders, primarily consuming microalgae and organic particles suspended in the water.
    • In tanks with low particulate matter, supplement their diet with liquid invertebrate foods designed for filter feeders.

  6. Tank mates:

    • These clams are peaceful and compatible with most community fish, shrimp, and non-aggressive tank mates.
    • Avoid large or digging fish that may disturb the substrate and stress the clams.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Mini Yellow Freshwater Clams are stationary, often found partially burrowed in the substrate as they filter nutrients from the water.
    • They do not reproduce in typical aquarium settings, so overpopulation is not a concern.

name: Shocking Pink Endler Guppy Pair (Poecilia Wingei)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Shocking Pink Endler Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia wingei
    • Common name: Shocking Pink Endler Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Venezuela
    • Adult length: 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Shocking Pink Endler Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 20L, but larger tanks with more space are preferred.
    • Include live plants and hiding spots to provide security and stimulate natural behaviors.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a slightly alkaline to neutral pH in the range of 7.0 to 8.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide gentle filtration as Shocking Pink Endler Guppies prefer slower water flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Shocking Pink Endler Guppies are omnivores and thrive on a diet of high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods like daphnia and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size.
    • Compatible tank mates include small tetras, rasboras, and peaceful dwarf cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Shocking Pink Endler Guppies are active and display schooling behavior, so it's recommended to keep them in groups for their well-being.
    • Avoid aggressive tank mates that may stress or harass them.

name: Olive Green Nerite Snail (Neritina reclivata)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Olive Green Nerite Snails

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Neritina reclivata
    • Common name: Olive Green Nerite Snail
    • Family: Neritidae
    • Origin: Coastal and freshwater rivers in North and Central America
    • Adult length: 2-3 cm
    • Lifespan: 1 to 2 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Olive Green Nerite Snails do well in tanks with hard surfaces like rocks, driftwood, and tank walls where they can graze on algae.
    • A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small group of snails.
    • Keep a secure lid on the tank, as these snails may occasionally climb out.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • They prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.5, which is beneficial for their shells.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 22 to 28°C (72 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is ideal, allowing the snails to graze comfortably without disturbance from strong currents.
    • Ensure good water quality, as Olive Green Nerite Snails are sensitive to ammonia and nitrate levels.

  5. Diet:

    • These snails primarily feed on algae, making them valuable for controlling algae growth in the tank.
    • If natural algae are insufficient, supplement their diet with algae wafers or blanched vegetables like cucumber or zucchini.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Olive Green Nerite Snails are peaceful and compatible with most community fish, including tetras, rasboras, and shrimp.
    • Avoid housing them with aggressive, snail-eating fish like certain loaches and pufferfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • These snails are calm and spend much of their time grazing, helping to keep tank surfaces clean.
    • They do not reproduce in freshwater, eliminating the risk of overpopulation in typical home aquariums.

name: Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platy (Xiphophorus Maculatus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Xiphophorus maculatus
    • Common name: Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Central America, from southern Mexico to Guatemala
    • Adult length: 3 to 7 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 4 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platies are adaptable and can thrive in various tank sizes, but a minimum of 20L per fish is recommended to ensure adequate space.
    • They appreciate a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming areas.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platies prefer slightly alkaline water with a pH range of 7.0 to 8.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle to moderate water flow is suitable for Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse platies, so choose a filter that provides adequate but not excessive flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platies are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platies are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other peaceful species such as tetras, guppies, mollies, and peaceful barbs.
    • They should not be kept with aggressive or fin-nipping species that may stress or harm them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Metallic Blue Mickey Mouse Platies are active swimmers and are best kept in groups of at least five individuals to ensure social interaction and minimize stress.
    • They are known for their peaceful nature and can coexist with a variety of tank mates.

name: Hikari Sinking Carnivore Pellets 74g
description:
Sinking Carnivore Pellets

Sponge like sinking pellet ideal for most carnivores

  • Specifically developed for bottom feeding carnivorous fish
  • Offers a nutrient mix comparable with live foods without the parasites or bacteria they normally contain
  • Developed on the back of extensive studies into the sight, smell and taste of numerous carnivorous fish
  • Includes the highest grade of colour enhancing ingredients to support colour retention in UV deficient environments, ensuring fish look their best all year round
  • Rapidly become soft when absorbing water whilst retaining its desirable shape
  • Floating, protein rich (min 47%) pellet
  • Pack size: 74g

Ideal for:

Most carnivorous fish especially non-surface feeders such as catfish, sharks, polypterus (bichirs), eels and stingrays.

Feeding:

Feed two to three times daily the amount your fish will completely consume in a few minutes. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding. Carnivorous fish may resist a new type of food when changing their diet, but continued use will assure acceptance.

name: Hikari Vibra Bites 125g
description:
Vibra Bites

Bloodworm like stick that offers outstanding nutrition and exceptional colour enhancing properties

  • Includes carefully selected colour enhancing ingredients including carotenoids
  • Scientifically developed nutrient mix to bring out fishes natural brilliant colouring
  • Worm like stick specifically designed to look like bloodworm
  • Sticks move slowly and randomly through the water mimicking bloodworm
  • Completely safe live food alternative -offers all the nutritional benefits of live foods without the risk of parasites or bacteria
  • The inclusion of krill and cuttlefish meal, mealworms and silkworms make this a delicious offering that most tropical fish will go for immediately
  • Complete and balanced daily diet
  • Pack sizes: 35g, 73g, 280g

Ideal for:

Small and medium sized tropical fish.

Feeding:

Feed 2 to 4 times daily the amount your pet will consume within a few minutes. Always remove any uneaten food after the feeding period.

name: Hikari Massivore Delite 380g
description:
Massivore Delite

Scientifically developed diet for super-sized bottom feeding carnivorous fish

  • Extremely palatable diet most larger carnivorous fish eagerly attack 
  • Extra large porous pellet that softens quickly
  • Includes the highest grade of carotenoids for excellent colouration 
  • Sinking, protein rich (min 47%) pellet
  • Pack size: 380g

Ideal for:

Monster carnivores especially catfish, sharks, polypterus (bichirs), eels and carnivorous plecostomus.

Feeding:

Feed once a day, an amount your fish will eat within a few minutes. Carnivorous fish may resist a new type of food when changing from live foods or less protein rich diets, but continued use will assure acceptance. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding and always remove uneaten food after the feeding period.
Note: Hikari Massivore Delite contains high levels of natural ingredients which may result in a slight change in colour from one pack to another. You can be rest assured that Hikari's stringent quality standards and processes ensure that every pack meets a specific nutritional specification.

name: Hikari Floating Cichlid Gold Medium Pellet 57g
description:
A complete and balanced diet for Carnivorous Cichlids and Larger Tropical Fish requiring higher protein levels

  • Rapid nutrient utilisation with minimal waste
  • Protein rich formulation promotes excellent growth
  • Sizes: Baby, Mini, Medium & Large pellets
  • Pack sizes: Baby – 250g; Mini – 57g, 250g; Medium – 57g, 250g; Large – 250g

Ideal for:

All types of cichlids or larger tropical fish that require higher protein levels or assistance with colour development.

Feeding:

Feed two to three times daily the amount your fish will completely consume in a few minutes. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding and always remove uneaten food after the feeding period.

name: Hikari Algae Wafers 82g
description:
Algae Wafers

The original and best algae wafer

  • Scientifically developed for Plecostomus and other algae eating fish including marine herbivores
  • Perfect balance of premium quality ingredients developed to promote proper growth and desirable form
  • Complete and balanced diet
  • Rich in natural green algae, helping promote excellent colouring
  • Easy and convenient way to feed
  • Revolutionary disc shape complements the way Plecostomus eat
  • Pack sizes: 20g, 40g, 82g, 250g, 1kg

Ideal for:

Plecostomus and other algae eating fish including marine herbivores.

Feeding:

Feed no more than the amount your fish will completely consume within 2 hours. Many bottom feeders are nocturnal, for best results feed late in the day or at night. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding and always remove uneaten food after feeding period

name: Albino Senegal Bichir (Polypterus senegalus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Albino Senegal Bichir Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Polypterus senegalus
    • Common name: Albino Senegal Bichir
    • Family: Polypteridae
    • Origin: West and Central Africa, including the Nile River and Senegal River basins
    • Adult length: Can grow up to 35 cm (14 inches)
    • Lifespan: Typically 10 to 15 years, but can live longer with proper care

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Albino Senegal Bichirs require a spacious tank with plenty of floor space for exploring. A minimum tank size of 75 gallons is recommended for an adult specimen.
    • Provide hiding spots using caves, PVC pipes, or large rocks, as they are nocturnal and like to hide during the day.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Albino Senegal Bichirs prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Maintain a water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A good filtration system is essential to maintain water quality, as Albino Senegal Bichirs are messy eaters and produce a lot of waste.
    • Ensure the filter provides gentle to moderate flow, as strong currents may stress them.

  5. Diet:

    • Albino Senegal Bichirs are carnivorous and prefer meaty foods. Offer them a varied diet including live or frozen foods such as bloodworms, blackworms, earthworms, and shrimp.
    • They may also accept high-quality sinking pellets or carnivore-specific commercial foods.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Albino Senegal Bichirs are generally solitary and may become aggressive towards conspecifics or other bottom-dwelling fish.
    • Compatible tank mates include larger, peaceful species that inhabit different areas of the tank, such as large characins, catfish, or cichlids from similar regions.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Albino Senegal Bichirs are nocturnal and prefer to hide during the day, so provide plenty of hiding spots in the aquarium.
    • They have poor eyesight but a keen sense of smell, relying on their sensitive barbels to locate food.

name: Strawberry Leporinus (Leporinus sp)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Strawberry Leporinus Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Leporinus sp. “strawberry”
    • Common name: Strawberry Leporinus
    • Family: Anostomidae
    • Origin: South America (Amazon River basin)
    • Adult length: Varies depending on species, generally ranges from 10 to 30 cm
    • Lifespan: Approximately 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Strawberry Leporinus require a tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 75 gallons is recommended for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide hiding places using rocks, driftwood, or artificial caves. They also appreciate dense vegetation and open areas for swimming.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Strawberry Leporinus prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A powerful filtration system is essential to maintain water quality due to their messy eating habits and high activity levels.
    • Provide moderate to strong water flow to mimic their natural habitat.

  5. Diet:

    • Strawberry Leporinus are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods.
    • Supplement their diet with vegetables like zucchini, spinach, and blanched peas, along with protein-rich foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Strawberry Leporinus are generally peaceful but can be territorial, especially during breeding periods. They are best kept with similarly sized, robust fish that can hold their own.
    • Compatible tank mates include medium to large-sized peaceful community fish such as larger tetras, barbs, cichlids, and catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Strawberry Leporinus are active swimmers and may jump, so a tightly fitting lid is necessary.
    • They may exhibit some aggression towards conspecifics or similar-looking fish, especially if kept in insufficiently large groups or in cramped quarters.

name: Rosy Danio (Danio roseus)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Rosy Danio Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Danio roseus
    • Common name: Rosy Danio
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Asia
    • Adult length: Varies (typically around 4 cm)
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Rosy Danios prefer a spacious tank with plenty of swimming space. A minimum tank size of 20L is recommended for a small school of these fish.
    • Provide ample hiding places and areas with dense vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They appreciate plants like Java Fern, Anubias, and floating plants like Amazon Frogbit.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Rosy Danios thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A moderate water flow is suitable for these fish, so choose a filter that provides gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Rosy Danios are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food as a staple.
    • Supplement their diet with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia to provide essential nutrients and mimic their natural diet.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Rosy Danios are peaceful schooling fish and should be kept in groups of at least six individuals to prevent stress and encourage their natural behaviors.
    • They are compatible with other peaceful community fish such as other tetras, rasboras, peaceful barbs, and small catfish species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Rosy Danios are active swimmers and display schooling behavior, so they feel more secure and exhibit their best colors when kept in a group.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or fin-nipping fish species that may intimidate or harass them.

name: Tiger Endler Guppy Pair (Poecilia wingei)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Tiger Endler Guppy Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Poecilia wingei
    • Common name: Tiger Endler Guppy
    • Family: Poeciliidae
    • Origin: Venezuela
    • Adult length: 2.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 2 to 3 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Tiger Endler Guppies are small fish and can thrive in tanks as small as 20L, but larger tanks with more space are preferred.
    • Include live plants and hiding spots to provide security and stimulate natural behaviors.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain a slightly alkaline to neutral pH in the range of 7.0 to 8.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide gentle filtration as Tiger Endler Guppies prefer slower water flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Tiger Endler Guppies are omnivores and thrive on a diet of high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods like daphnia and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and can be kept with other peaceful community fish of similar size.
    • Compatible tank mates include small tetras, rasboras, and peaceful dwarf cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Tiger Endler Guppies are active and display schooling behavior, so it's recommended to keep them in groups for their well-being.
    • Avoid aggressive tank mates that may stress or harass them.

name: Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish (Pterophyllum scalare)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Pterophyllum scalare
    • Common name: Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 years or more

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish require a tall tank with a capacity of at least 200L to accommodate their vertical swimming behavior.
    • Provide tall plants like Amazon Sword and Vallisneria for them to hide among, and leave open swimming spaces in the middle and upper parts of the tank.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Provide gentle to moderate water flow with a suitable filter to maintain water quality without causing excessive disturbance.

  5. Diet:

    • Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods. Offer them a balanced diet consisting of high-quality flake or pellet food supplemented with live or frozen foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish are generally peaceful but can be territorial during breeding. They are compatible with other peaceful community fish such as tetras, rasboras, gouramis, and corydoras catfish.
    • Avoid keeping them with aggressive or very small fish that they may see as prey.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Dark Blue Smokey Angelfish are known for their graceful swimming and striking appearance, making them a popular choice for community tanks.
    • They may exhibit some aggression during breeding, so provide ample hiding spots and tank space if breeding is intended.

name: Hikari Crab Cuisine 50g
description:
Crab Cuisine
Daily diet for all types of Crustaceans including Hermit Crabs, Lobsters, Crayfish and Tadpoles

Enriched with calcium to help develop and maintain shell structure
Rapidly sinking pellet that retains its shape and doesn't cloud the water
Pack size: 50g
Ideal for:
Freshwater and marine aquariums to feed scavengers, reducing the chances they will attack other pets.

Feeding:
For lobsters, shrimp, underwater crawfish and other aquatic scavengers, feed 1-4 sticks twice a day based on size. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding and always remove uneaten food after feeding period.
For hermit crabs feed in a clean shallow dish once a week, removing the food from the enclosure after 24 hours. Feed an amount equal to 2 grams of food (approximately a thimble full) for each hermit crab per feeding.

name: Hikari Sinking Wafers 50g
description:
Sinking Wafers
Unique wafer shape for all bottom feeders

Complete and balanced diet
Soft wafer developed for bottom feeders which have downward facing mouths and gulp their food
Palatable and aromatic blend will attract even the most picky eaters
Contains Spirulina, Silkworm and Krill
Easily digested, low waste formula
Unique shaped disc becomes soft gradually
Pack sizes: 25g, 50g, 110g
Ideal for:
Bottom feeders such as Corydoras Catfish, Loaches and other small bottom feeders.

Feeding:
Feed the amount your fish will completely consume in 20 minutes. Care should be taken to avoid over-feeding and always remove any uneaten food after feeding period to avoid water clouding.

name: NT Labs Pro-f Axolotl Junior Pellet 60g
description:
For Amphibians

Pro-f Axolotl Pellets are a quick-sinking complete food, especially formulated to meet the dietary requirements of your axolotl, newts or African clawed frogs. These high-protein pellets are fortified with vitamins and minerals to support their physiology, while the blend of ingredients makes these pellets highly palatable. The fish meal and fish oil gives the pellet a strong odour encouraging even the fussiest axolotl to feed. This completely removes the risk of transferring pathogens associated with feeding live foods. Axolotl Pellets are very low in waste, whilst the inclusion of Stimmune keeps them healthy and in the best possible condition.

name: NT Labs Aquarium Lab Multi-Test Kit
description: The main factor in successful fish keeping and health lies in the maintenance of good water quality. Ammonia, nitrite and pH levels in the aquarium should be checked regularly. The Aquarium Lab Multi-Test Kit comprises up to 200 tests combined of the 6 key parameters to test in your aquarium: ammonia, nitrite, nitrate, pH, GH and KH. All the tests are liquid drop tests from a dropper bottle so all the drops are the same size. Full instructions are included detailing optimum levels and suggestions for correction, along with an integrated test tube rack. All you have to do is add your aquarium water to the test tube and count the drops needed. The back of the box details clear pictorial instructions so you can see what to do from the start. A set of colour coded stickers is provided to label both the test tubes and test tube lids so you always conduct the same test in the same test tube avoiding contamination.

defaultImage.altText: NT Labs Aquarium Lab Multi-Test Kit

name: Betta AP-2000 Air Pump
description: The Betta AP-2000 Silent Aquarium Air Pump is recommended for aquariums up to 60L. Suitable for use with standard 4/6mm airline and compatible accessories such as Betta Air stones, Air Curtains, air-operated aquarium ornaments, plus under-gravel and other air-driven filters (not included). It is great for increasing the oxygen levels in your aquarium.

name: Drape Fin Barb (Oreichthys crenuchoides)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Drape Fin Barb Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Oreichthys crenuchoides
    • Common name: Drape Fin Barb
    • Family: Cyprinidae
    • Origin: Western Ghats in India
    • Adult length: 4.5 cm
    • Lifespan: 3 to 5 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Drape Fin Barbs prefer a well-planted tank with open swimming spaces. A tank size of 40L or more is suitable for a small group of these fish.
    • Provide hiding spots with rocks, caves, and driftwood. They appreciate a setup that mimics the natural stream environment.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0.
    • Keep the water temperature between 22 to 26°C (72 to 79°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • A gentle water flow is suitable for these fish. Use a filter that provides adequate but not strong flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Drape Fin Barbs are omnivores. Offer them a balanced diet of high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like small worms and insects.
    • Include vegetable matter in their diet, such as spirulina-based foods and blanched vegetables.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful community fish and can be kept with other small, non-aggressive species. Good tank mates include small rasboras, tetras, and peaceful bottom dwellers.
    • Avoid keeping them with larger or aggressive fish that may intimidate them.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Drape Fin Barbs are social fish and should be kept in groups of at least six individuals.
    • They may display some territorial behavior, especially during breeding, so provide sufficient hiding spots to reduce aggression.

name: Panda Angelfish (Pterophyllum scalare)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Panda Angelfish Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Pterophyllum scalare "Panda"
    • Common name: Panda Angelfish
    • Family: Cichlidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: 15 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Panda Angelfish require a tank with a minimum size of 75L, and taller tanks are preferable due to their vertical swimming nature.
    • Provide tall plants and decorations to mimic their natural environment, and leave open swimming spaces at the top.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Panda Angelfish thrive in slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.
    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 29°C (75 to 84°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Choose a filter with moderate flow to maintain water quality without causing excessive turbulence.

  5. Diet:

    • Panda Angelfish are omnivores; include a variety of high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods like brine shrimp and bloodworms in their diet.
    • Ensure a balanced diet to promote their health and vibrant colors.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Panda Angelfish are generally peaceful but may become territorial during breeding. Compatible tankmates include other peaceful community fish like tetras, rasboras, and dwarf cichlids.
    • Avoid aggressive or fin-nipping species that may stress the Panda Angelfish.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Panda Angelfish are known for their graceful swimming and can be kept in pairs or small groups.
    • They may become more territorial during breeding, so provide adequate hiding spaces to reduce aggression.

name: L128 Blue Phantom Pleco (Hemiancistrus sp) 5-7
description:
Our Guide To Keeping L128 Blue Phantom Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Hemiancistrus sp.
    • Common name: Blue Phantom Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America, specifically the Xingu River basin
    • Adult length: Up to 20 cm (8 inches)
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Blue Phantom Plecos require a tank size of at least 100 gallons.
    • Provide caves, driftwood, and hiding spots as they are nocturnal and appreciate hiding during the day.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain water temperature between 25 to 30°C (77 to 86°F).
    • Water pH should be slightly acidic to neutral, ideally between 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water clean and well-oxygenated with regular water changes.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a strong filtration system to ensure good water quality.
    • Provide moderate water flow in the tank.

  5. Diet:

    • Blue Phantom Plecos are omnivores and require a varied diet.
    • Offer them sinking algae wafers, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are generally peaceful but can be territorial with their own species.
    • Compatible tank mates include peaceful community fish like tetras, rasboras, and peaceful cichlids.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Blue Phantom Plecos are nocturnal and will be more active during the night.
    • They are generally peaceful but may become territorial towards other bottom-dwelling fish or similar plecos.

name: L200 Green Phantom Pleco (Hemiancistrus subviridis) 7-8cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping L200 Green Phantom Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Hemiancistrus subviridis
    • Common name: Green Phantom Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: Amazon River Basin in South America
    • Adult length: Up to 30 cm
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Green Phantom Plecos require a tank with hiding places such as caves and driftwood. A tank size of at least 75 gallons is recommended for adult specimens.
    • Provide a substrate with smooth rocks and driftwood to mimic their natural environment, and include plants like Java Fern and Anubias.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.5 to 7.5.
    • Keep the water temperature between 25 to 30°C (77 to 86°F).

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a strong filtration system to maintain water quality, and ensure good water flow in the tank.

  5. Diet:

    • Green Phantom Plecos are omnivores and accept a varied diet. Provide high-quality sinking pellets, wafers, and supplement with fresh vegetables like zucchini and cucumber.
    • Occasionally offer protein-rich foods such as bloodworms and brine shrimp.

  6. Tank mates:

    • Green Phantom Plecos are generally peaceful, but avoid keeping them with aggressive or territorial tank mates. They are compatible with other non-aggressive fish that share similar water parameters.
    • Ensure there is enough hiding space for each pleco to reduce potential territorial disputes.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • These plecos are nocturnal, so provide hiding places and dim lighting during the day. They are generally peaceful but can become territorial, especially during breeding.
    • Keep them in a species-specific tank or with other peaceful community fish that won't outcompete them for food.

name: Albino Sterba's Corydora (Corydoras sterbai)
description:
Our Guide To Keeping Albino Sterba's Cory Fish

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Corydoras sterbai
    • Common name: Albino Sterba's Cory
    • Family: Callichthyidae
    • Origin: Upper Rio Guaporé in Brazil
    • Adult length: 6 cm
    • Lifespan: 5 to 8 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Albino Sterba's Corys appreciate a tank with soft substrate and plenty of hiding places like caves, driftwood, and plants.
    • Ensure the tank has smooth decorations to prevent damage to their delicate barbels.

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Maintain the water temperature between 24 to 26°C (75 to 79°F).
    • They prefer slightly acidic to neutral water conditions with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.5.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Avoid strong water currents as Sterba's Corys prefer calmer waters. Opt for a filter with gentle to moderate flow.

  5. Diet:

    • Albino Sterba's Corys are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including sinking pellets, flakes, and frozen or live foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp.
    • Feed them sinking foods as they are bottom-dwellers and may not compete well for food at the surface.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They are peaceful and should be kept in groups of at least six individuals.
    • Compatible tank mates include other peaceful community fish like tetras, rasboras, dwarf cichlids, and other Corydoras species.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Albino Sterba's Corys are social and active bottom-dwellers, often seen scavenging for food.
    • They are compatible with most peaceful tank mates but avoid keeping them with aggressive or large fish that may intimidate or prey on them.

name: L114 Leopard Cactus Pleco (Pseudacanthicus cf. leopardus) 10cm
description:
Our Guide To Keeping L114 Leopard Cactus Pleco

  1. About Fish Species:

    • Scientific name: Pseudacanthicus cf. leopardus
    • Common name: Leopard Cactus Pleco
    • Family: Loricariidae
    • Origin: South America, specifically the Amazon and Orinoco River basins
    • Adult length: Up to 15 cm (6 inches)
    • Lifespan: 10 to 15 years

  2. Tank Setup:

    • Leopard Cactus Plecos require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots among rocks, caves, and driftwood.
    • They prefer soft, acidic water with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0 and a temperature between 24 to 28°C (75 to 82°F).

  3. Water Parameters:

    • Keep the water quality high with regular water changes to maintain optimal conditions.
    • Provide good filtration to keep the water clean and well-oxygenated.

  4. Filtration and Water Flow:

    • Use a powerful filtration system to handle the waste produced by Leopard Cactus Plecos.
    • They prefer moderate to strong water flow in the tank.

  5. Diet:

    • Leopard Cactus Plecos are omnivores and will accept a variety of foods including sinking pellets, algae wafers, blanched vegetables, and occasional live or frozen foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp.
    • Ensure a well-rounded diet to meet their nutritional needs.

  6. Tank mates:

    • They can be territorial with their own kind, so it's best to keep one Leopard Cactus Pleco per tank unless you have a large aquarium with ample hiding spots.
    • They are generally peaceful with other fish species that are not aggressive and can tolerate their water requirements.

  7. Behavior and Compatibility:

    • Leopard Cactus Plecos are nocturnal and will spend much of the day hiding in caves or under driftwood.
    • They are generally peaceful but may become territorial, especially towards other bottom-dwelling fish.
